RATING: 6
Really good gateway game, it never missed the target so far. Simple rules, some strategic and tactical play and a good amount of luck, decent playing time (maybe a bit too long). The problem is that I bring this game to the table only with non gamers, due to its lack of variability, really interesting decisions and, in the end, any real depth. It's rummy with a board and some positional play. Still better than the original TtR, which is even lighter.

DoW version. Great components.

RATING: 5
Best at 3 or 4, it's the TTR edition I reach for when I'm playing with more than 3 (or more than 2 if I don't want as mean of a game that Nordic would create) as I find the map and long routes the most interesting. The stations are a nice touch if you get hosed on that long route or caught out near the end and use that last turn to try and complete something. In particular, the addition of the tunnels and ferries gives the game an edge of the US standard.

RATING: 6
Essentially an expansion map for Ticket to Ride shamelessly produced and priced as a whole board game.

Having another map for the original game is always nice but this one also adds two new features which are a step backwards, and that is the tunnels which are a push your luck aspect which makes a light game even lighter and more random, and the stations are almost pointless. Incredible that a lesser design (Europe vs original USA map) won a gaming award.


Own the [boardgame=53383]Europa 1912[/boardgame] expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride:  Europe is an above-average strategy game.  There's a lot of planning and you really have to try to figure out what your opponents are doing, otherwise, they might take valuable tracks before you can.  

There's a fairly good skill element to this game, but if I have a complaint, it's that there is a significant luck element in which routes you draw at the beginning of the game.  It can be difficult to win with some of the Western European routes, and there's one high-scoring route between two cities that vastly superior to all others.  In this sense, the game ends up being a bit like Risk in that there are really only maybe 3-4 viable winning strategies against good players.

All the same, it's still a fun game with a lot of strategy.  I think somewhere around a "7" is probably an appropriate rating.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2009/05
The stations are a good addon to the basic game but I'm not sure about the tunnels and ferries. Worst of the TTR series.

2014/10
Original = Best for families with 4-5 players, elegant rules, suffers from card hoarding strategy

Märklin = Most satisfactory for gamers, strong incentive to make early plays mitigating the hoarding problem, a bit fiddly

Nordic = Best for families with 2-3 players, slight hoarding problems which are mitigated by the tight map, random take that aspects due to the tunnel mechanics

Europe = worst of the bunch in all aspects

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
How to make a great game better?  Well, maybe.  I thought so at first, but now maybe not.

Having said that, anyone who likes TtR is almost bound to love this.  Here's some pointers as to what's good about this: the set up of the cities and the routes between them creates a different challenge (there are less double routes and more short routes); it's fun to see that one side of the board (the West) is very congested and the other is quite sparse and tends towards longer routes; there are many obvious blocking ponts...but; the new mechanism of stations helps to unblock those and I love the fact that if you chose to play one you effectively lose points at the end; the ferries add another interesting touch and thinking point; the tunnels are a (realistic) stroke of genius - there could have been lots of possibilites for how to model this but the way it's been done strikes me as perfect - after all digging tunnels could be a gamble - would you hit harder or weaker rock?; the length 8 route worth 21 points is great fun; the designer has made it more useful to pick up Locos (you need them!) and and to draw extra destination tickets; everyone gets one long route at the start (but doesn't have to use it) and that strikes me as a good leveller.  A smashing game that is significantly different from the original and more of a "gamer's-game."  I suppose some will try to adopt different rules from the two versions together.  I'm happy, for now, to have this, the original and the unofficial Belgian variant. I do, however, look forward to a future Mystery train Expansion for this.  And I'm excited enough to put forward some ideas  - Tunnelling Mole (burrow at normal cost), Ferry Owner - travel over ferries without locos, Station Master - play one station without losing points at the end.  The possibilities are exciting!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.43
Rating TTR series as a whole.

Even though this series jumped the shark back in 2010 (seriously, who plays Ticket to Ride so much that they need 18 different maps to play it on??), some of the earlier entries in the series are great.  Ticket to Ride is normally a go to game for newbies who have never tried a Euro style board game before.

The European edition is great for 4 to 5 players.  While there is still stress associated with claiming routes, the addition of the stations make losing a key route less game-breaking.  Over numerous plays, we have discovered that the player who draws the "Brest-Petrograd" long route at the beginning of the game seems to win a disproportionate share of the time.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A beautiful game, pretty lightweight, enjoyable to play with non-gamers and gamers (although, if I've got some gamers togehter I'd rather pull out something meatier). Doesn't feel substantially different from the original despite the changes (if I had to pick, I'd say that I like this one a little bit more).
Update 2005 05 14: I still slightly prefer this version to the original, but I wish I had bought the original. Why? Because there are just enough fiddly rules here, combined with a less accessible/ familiar map, to alienate the casual players this is aimed at. In the end, I wanted a game to pull out with the family, etc, so simpler would have been better. If I want a more strategic game, I'll choose an entirely different game.

RATING: 6
I played this game just three times, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

There're games with simple rules that are lots of fun. This game is not one of them. Ticket to Ride is not a bad game by any means but it is a very mediocre and disappointing one. I saw countless reviews and game-plays before buying it... and the game never sounded fun to me, but I ended up picking up a copy anyway. I needed a good gateway game to introduce people to the hobby during my Erasmus scholarship and on-line tons of people kept going over and over about Ticket to Ride being the best of them. So I decided to try it.

I understand that this is my opinion and experience, but Ticket to Ride really didn't work for me. I sincerely don't understand what is the fun of collecting cards turn after turn after turn, until you can finally play something. There's some tactics involved for sure, but the mechanics are really not exciting. It's the just same thing over and over again! Furthermore every time I played it, Ticket to Ride felt too long for what it is. I ended up wishing for the game to end and ironically so did the other people at the table: those that I wanted to introduce to board-gaming. I understand that TtR is a simple family game and it was wrong from me to expect more... maybe the hype ruined this for me, but I can also name a bunch of other family games that are way more fun and way better as gateway game. Terribly mediocre game.

The United Kingdom/Pennsylvania expansion brought some new life into this game and it actually made me enjoy it more. Yet I still think that Ticket to Ride is an average game that doesn't work for me.

Rating without expansion: 5.

RATING: 7
A neat train building game. The key is to build the longest continuous line in order to gain more points and win the game. You also must be strategic about which routes you pick and if you pick up more tickets as unfinished tickets incur a penalty in the final scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite games...!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love some of the new game elements in Ticket To Ride Europe. In particular, I like the new train stations, which let you use another player's route (but only once) to complete a ticket. I also like the new ticket distribution system, which makes sure that all players get one long route. At the beginning of the game, all the 20-21 pt. routes are shuffled and each player gets 1 long route and 3 regular route tickets - you must keep at least 2 of them (the other long route cards and any discarded tickets are removed from the game). I enjoy the TTRE map, but mostly because I like Europe better than U.S. for locations. I think the TtRE map is less accessible than the original one with less ways to get to targeted cities, and more restrictions on the cards needed to get there. The new tunnels and ferries force you to wait for the right cards to become available, which can be a hassle.

Now, if I used the train stations and new long route ticket distribution in the original TtR (especially with the Mystery Train Expansion), I think it would be better than both TtR and TtRE!

2015 UPDATE: This one stands the test of time. Still a good one!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A brilliantly designed game that is colourful, fun and easy to learn (unless you are my father who spent half the game waiting for the "brown" train cards to come up - he was in fact waiting for "orange.")

The best part about this game is that you don't know exactly who has won until the very end so it's all to play for. It's very satisfying to leap ahead of your opponents who think they are the clear winners.

You can also make it more strategic if you want it to be but I like the family friendly aspect of it all. 

Bad points would be that luck has a large part to do with it. If you get good starting ticket cards or draw several that have routes which you've practically already completed you are likely going to win.

RATING: 7
I like how this one fleshes out the TtR system, adding tighter choke points, but also a way to handle getting blocked (stations), or a press your luck element (tunnels), or really useful connections that are harder to complete (ferries). The map feels a lot more constrained (which hurts a touch its gateway appeal), and the destinations are foreign to a State-sider (also hurting its gateway appeal). I personally don't see how this is appreciably better than USA (maybe I need to play with the Europe expansion), but it's nice for a change of pace.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ticket to Ride Europe is an improvement over the original and 
I regard it even better as Ticket to Ride Märklin. The Europe map is more balanced than the USA one. However the tunneling and the mandatory joker cards do not add much. 

The newly added stations however are a big improvement. You are no longer annoyed by broken routes, but suffer a victory point penalty instead. 

TtR:E lacks in scalability. The number of trains (45) does not vary with the number of players. And that matters!

Like the other games in the TtR series, a fun and fastplaying game. Not in game length, but in time per player per turn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Perfect family game. Easy to teach and play with nice board and theme. Even my grandma likes it! The Europe edition is more relaxed than the original because it is hard to block your opponents.

[4]2-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
The new standard for entry games. The best of the series with the routes and depots taking some of the luck out of the original game. 

Complexity - simple, you draw cards, place trains from cards in hand, or draw new tickets

Strategy - moderate, you have to be flexible. Being bold and managing your trains will net you a high score but you have to be timely and efficient or the game will end too soon for you. 

Luck - moderate, you have no say in what cards are available, what routes and train cards you draw randomly, only how to place them. Even the most flexible strategies can get beat by a good draw. 

Interaction - very high. Almost everything you do effects other players. There is a chance nobody will want to go to the areas you do or get the colored trains you have but that is not the case most of the time. 

Fun - with the luck factor moderate many skill levels can compete and first time players can even win. You can enjoy this game with friends but not if you are hoping a grand matter plan will win you the game for certain.

RATING: 8
2.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A nice, fast warm-up club game - the more players, the better and tenser it gets - overall a refinement of the original T2R.

A few points which may have been made by others: 1) You can discard the long routes and opt for the "many short routes" strategy 2) Despite the "easy to memorize" long routes, you can be stealthy about which one you have. 3) The timing of when to play those stations as the game comes to its swift and tense end is a fun addition to the end game 4) The tunnels encourage more strategic planning. I've found that only in a desperate bid for points in an end game will I play for a tunnel without a hand margin of at least one extra.

RATING: 6
{2 plays, 4 & 5 player} I really like the Everyone Gets Only 1 Long Ticket thing, but, especially with 5 players, I hated the congestion.  There's something ultimately friendly about Ticket to Ride, and in turning it into more of gamer's game, it got a little evil.  Even worse, it didn't feel like a balanced evil - it seemed like the players on the East side of the board were in fewer fights.  And the track sort of bears this out, as the stuff on the East side is "harder" to complete - more locomotives, more tunnels, etc.  Interestingly enough, in a 4-player game NO ONE needed to use a station, whereas the 5-player game saw two players use at least one, and one use two (and ALL of those players lost to, you guessed it, the player who had the Eastern routes).  I definitely prefer the original.

RATING: 6
A nice game, easy to learn, a game where you have to plan ahead. However, there are very few player interactions (at least not conscious ones), a point I miss in this game. The original game's map makes for more route blocking, and thus enables you to effectively block other players.

Because of that, I actually prefer the original edition, although I like the idea of having separate long- and short-distance destination tickets (I'm not so positive about the train stations, but they are sometimes necessary, given the map).

Was well-received by my marginal-gamer friends.

RATING: 7
This feels more like a second edition than its own game.  There are some additional game play elements like tunnels, but the core game is mostly identical.  The production quality is higher and more refined in this edition than the original (if you own a first printing - later printings add in the same improvements that Tt2R: Europe does).  Some player may find the language choice and spelling of the cities as frstrating since they are not the US names.  Visually, this is a better game than the first, but it does not get the table time that the first does.  [GTI: TGCL]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love Ticket to Ride, and I love this version. I own both the US map and Europe. If you have played the US map, then you know the basic idea is to build a train that connects points on a map. Same thing here, but because Europe is a more condensed area, you get the addition of train stations - which allow players to use opponents' routes in one direction. It also adds tunnels, where players must (after placing their train cars) draw three additional cars from the ticket deck. If one or more of those cards matches the color of cards the player placed to claim the route (or is a locomotive), the player must play additional tickets from their hand accordingly to successfully claim the tunnel. Europe also adds double routes to again account for Europe being more compact. That helps to lessen the chances of access being cut off to certain cities. In sum, I enjoy this version more, because it adds a tiny bit more complexity than the original. 8/10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

With 2 players we take out 2nd routes where they exist.

10/02/09 - Bumped the rating up to a 8 after several plays.

Rating: 
8 for 4 players
7 for 2 players (take out redundant routes)

RATING: 1.9
The third serious boardgame (after Carcassonne and Settlers) which I ever played. Got it for its reputation as a gateway game, but for me it nearly functioned as the opposite. The game takes far too long (and has too much downtime) for the rather severe lack of meaningful strategy or player interaction. A pointless waste of time.
Not as horrible with 2 players (and presumably with 3) as with more, though still completely lacking in strategic aspects.

I traded this away for El Grande in the Essen 2012 math trade.

RATING: 7.5
Just bought it. Will post my comments as soon as I give it a try!

UPDATE: I've just played 2 games with my wife, and so far, it's a very nice game. It's true it has a lot of luck with the card draws, but your approach can usually be modified according to the cards you have. Maybe a card exchange mechanic would have been nice, though.

UPDATE: Good game, but getting a little bit tired of the luck of the draw over the strategies chosen as a determining factor.

UPDATE: I didn't realize how much fun this game was. We've played a lot of times now, and still enjoy it. The only filler I find more fun than this one would be my new Thebes. Up to an 8, again.

UPDATE: Still like it, but not as much as before. Down to a 7.

RATING: 5.5
Not nearly enough player interaction to be interesting. It seems mainly that each player individually just gets on building his or her routes, which may or may not inadvertently result in another player having to make a detour. The large element of luck in the draw of the cards, not to mention those tunnels, doesn't help.
It's really a children's game, or one for non-gamers. I'll happily play with my family but would prefer something that feels like I'm playing against my opponents, rather than just in parallel to them.

RATING: 6
Szerintem jobb, mint az eredeti. A pluszok (alagút, komp, állomás) kifejezetten előnyére váltak, nem mintha az alap játékkal komolyabb bajom lett volna. Ráadásul nagyon igényes is a játék (kártyák, doboz...). 
Hárman játszottuk, talán ezért volt meglepően rövid. Kevesebb, mint egy óra (bár ez a hivatalosnak megfelel, mégis az alapjátékkal 2-3 óráig játszottunk). Mire minden kiosztott célt teljesítettünk, vége is lett a játéknak, így egyetlen egyszer sem húztunk új küldetést...
---
Pár év szünet után újra előkerült. Szomorú, de találtunk egy stratégiát, ami kicsit unalmassá teszi, túl domináns: csak a 2 legegyszerűbb kis célt kell megtartani az elején, gyorsan megcsinálni, és a továbbiakban nem is törődni a célokkal, ehelyett rámenni a hosszabb szakaszokra (8,6,4,4,4,4...), minél gyorsabban kipörgeti a vonatokat, hogy hamar vége legyen, így a komolyabb célkártyáknak esélye sincs.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not only the best "gateway" game ever created, the TTR series might have the best rules of any game in recent history. The games are simple, play quickly, have great components, and offer a ton of fun choices. The European version is slightly more complicated than the American version, but still increadibly simple. The changes in the European version make scoring with a lot of destination tickets a more viable strategy than in the American version. It is also harder to block your opponent, so this version doesn't feel as cut-throat. Despite being slightly more complicated, I think the changes in this version make it easier for kids and novices to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2-5 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is very similar to Ticket to Ride (US). I get bored pretty quickly waiting for my turn to put my four trains. You can put a lot of thought and strategy into it, but so many times you can be blocked by the other players. This and the US version are two games I could play at the same time and just switch back and forth until its my turn. There's no interaction while it's not your turn, so I end up chatting with other people while I wait or watching another game until it's my turn. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This version is much better than the original (which I would rate a 6).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
TTR-E gets a 1 from me because, for the Ticket to Ride series, this game is broken.  By means of the stations it removes the thing I love most about Ticket to Ride.  It doesn't have the nice push-your-luck feel of "Do I need to claim that route now or can I wait and take those cards that I really need?" On top of that the ferries are incredibly annoying.  A wild suddenly is not a wild.  As soon as you get a wild in your hand you know exactly which piece of track it will cover with little to no flexibility to be able to use it elsewhere.  Tunnels are only slightly less annoying but it does seem a good way to simulate the unknowns of building a tunnel.

My recommendation - try TTR-Marklin.  It magnifies the push-your-luck feel with passengers and is much much better in every way!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a great game to play when you want to have something in your hands while you talk.  The game is beautiful, the way the game mechanics are executed during play are easy to understand and smooth.  However, there simply isn't a great deal of depth of strategy (i.e. build routes for the best point efficiency) and there is more luck involved than I prefer (i.e. I've completed my long route I hope I can get lucky and draw some shorter routes that are within my longer route for some easy points).  I've downgraded its rating from 7 to 6 (this edit 2.8.12) because I've it enough and other boardgames to now know it is a great game to introduce to people who are intimidated by board games, and/or, as I mentioned earlier, have something in your hands and on the table while you socialize.

EDIT 3.5.12 - Game no longer available for trade.

RATING: 4
First play: Its many years since I last played TtR and as i was reminded of the rules I remember why I traded it after that last game. This is a very light family game. The card engine is so overpowering, you really are taken for a ride with little chance to steer the action. If you conicidentally draw routes which are similar to others you will struggle. Pick up routes isolated from the rest and you will breese through. Also linkable routes that fall in your lap and so will 10 points for the longets route.

At its most demeaning this is a very childish game will little scope for applied skill, just pray the right cards come up for you and the wrong ones for everyone else. Not to be played again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Greatly improved version of Ticket to Ride. This time, every player is guaranteed one long ticket worth around 20 points. Additionally, each player has train depots which allow a player to count someone else's trains entering or leaving a city as their own, but only when determining whether a destination ticket is complete. 

The cards are now full sized, which greatly improves upon the original experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have modified the game so that players can choose the order in which they can pick up the next round of revealed cards, and that order determines the order the players pick the following round.  The players always see two rounds of cards before they pick the order so that they can make a more informed decision.

RATING: 6
Good game, lots of depth...but sadly it's in that no-man's land between "comes out for newbies" and "heavy enough for gamers".

01-02-11: Not a bad game, but I didn't have a moment in playing a 4-player regular game with just the 19 additional routes for the 1912 where I was even a little bit mad, or even disappointed.  

I think this game is probably the worst of the series if you're playing with people who are nice to you.  If you can leave a two-spot wildcard open that you're clearly trying to get, and not have it filled by someone jerking you around...this is not the game to play.  You have so very many options available to you, if you don't work against eachother to exhaust those options, this game becomes a good example of virtual multiplayer solitaire.  

At least with the other games, there was contention, even if it's accidental.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I only played this once, and I recorded that play on the USA version. There are few differences but I think I'd enjoy them more if I had already been an experienced TtR player. Anyway, my thoughts:

-Ferries: Ok. Add a bit more difficulty and decisions to the game.

-Tunels: Meh. Adds more press-your-luck to a game that already had enough for my tastes (in the sense that every time you're not building you're pressing your luck that others do not claim your route), as you have to either have enough cards on the color you're building to counter the possible cards you're digging (which is like making the same route but 3 pieces longer) or build ahead and hope those cards don't show up.

-Stations: I don't really like pieces that twist the rules of the game to make it "easier" (Another one beingthe Abbey in Carcassonne, for example).

Overall, I think I'd rather play the original TtR.

Last note: The geography in this map is quite fucked up, really. I understand it's needed to make the routes the way they are, but that doesn't mean I have to like it...

RATING: 9
The best in the series (IMHO). Less cut throat than the other games in the series. Additional features add more thought while not bogging the game down. Just brilliant. 

My rating is for the four-player game, which I believe is the sweet spot for the game. Four players is less claustrophobic and gives a great deal of variety in the game play that I feel is a little absent from the three- and five-player games. Two player can be quite interesting, giving players a similar level of freedom to the four-player game.

See my [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/1594498]review[/url] for my full thoughts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm not crazy about the changes to the original.  The ferries are the only thing I enjoy.  The stations seem to ruin the point of the game (snap up routes early vs. hoard cards), the tunnels actually penalize you even further for going for smaller routes (the points system penalized this already), and separating the long routes from the short in the shuffle sounds good in theory, but there just aren't enough different long routes.  It's build on the back of a great game, so there's only so bad it can be really, but this does not stack up to the original in my eyes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ticket to Ride: Europe (2005) 		7.5  -7
I find Ticket to Ride is the perfect gateway game for non-gamers, since it’s easy to learn, plays smoothly and in the end it even feels like playing a bigger or harder game as it constantly requires the players to make relevant decisions and overcome new obstacles: its mix of simplicity and complexity is enough for me to make it one of the best games to play with anyone, no matter how much «gamers» they are.

This Europe edition though, which essentially is the same as the original game, simply adds a new map and a couple of new rules that don’t change the gameplay heavily but bring in an unnecessary layer of difficulty. [i](April 2014)[/i]

[b]Update [/b] - One of the goals I set for my Fall 2015 rating revise was to limit half-point ratings to a handful of games and Ticket to Ride Europe isn’t one of them: thus I rounded down my rating from 7,5 to 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Our family metagame for all TTR games is fairly nonconfrontational -- aggressive blocking (as opposed to incidental blocking) is stigmatized. This allows me, for most of the other TTR games, to have a preferred route that covers a good spread of tickets. Europe's ticket distribution doesn't allow this as much as US/Nordic/Swiss, which results in a more competitive game for all involved.

RATING: N/A
Get a 6th train set w/ train stations. In a 6 player game you just divide the 225 trains by 6 players, so each player gets 37 train tokens. How can you do this? Take 8 of each color and set them aside.

RATING: 8
A really good light game this.  There is enough strategy to satisfy those that need it and the rules are simple enough for it to serve as an introduction to 'Euro' games.  With three or more players it can be tense too as tracks start to get used up and you are trying to make a particular route.  Deciding whether or not to take another route can be the key to winning (or losing badly!).

RATING: 6
Another train game, but unlike the others I know, this one doesw not involve any goods shipping, it's just about building routes. Route objectives are handed out initially on cards and you can take more cards whenever you like. An interesting concept!

The card collecting mechanism used for building the routes across Europe is is pretty engaging and if you know the routes, then you can guess where your opponents are going. Blocking others and progresing yourself is part of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The Ticket to Ride series is essentially a Rummy variant with a spacial element.  However, the spacial element makes it substantially more complicated than traditional rummy, since it drives the colors and number of cards you need for each "meld", determines the scoring value of the melds, and acts as a game clock to determine when the game ends.  

This is an excellent game for casual or non gamers.  It is easily explained, and the strategy is not particularly complex.  The stations of the Europe variant make it more forgiving, and the tunnels and ferrys add some much needed value to the locomotive cards.  This is an excellent version to have on hand for when you want to pull out a game with visitors who do not usually game, or who are card gamers.  

Ticket to Ride does not have much depth to it, and the Europe version is particularly shallow, in that there are only 3 "big" routes - 1 8 train, and 2 6 train.  These are worth so many points that if one player grabs 2 of them, that player will likely win.  This is unthematic and a little disappointing, because it pulls the focus off building tickets and makes it a race to large numbers of the same color card.  However, the game is relatively quick to play (45-60 minutes with 4), and is good light fun. 

This game is also appropriate for young children, especially boys who are fascinated with trains.  I have found that my 5 year old can play competently with a little help.  The basic decisions (which color cards to take, when to take tickets) are good for teaching thinking ahead and basic strategy. 

Overall, I would probably not ever request TTR:E, but there are many situations that it is right for, and it has definitely earned its spot in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
 * RODZINNA
Plansza, karty, masa plastikowych wagoników  K

Por ahora me ha funcionado muy bien para introducir al juego y se nota la tensión según avanza la partida. En resumen un imprescindible en cualquier ludoteca. RATING: 8
Better than the original in nearly every aspect.  One long ticket   choose shorter tickets solves the long route problem.  The lack of the long track segments of the original removes that problem and evens the game out with those who must build more shorter routes.  It is now a necessity to get wild cards - you can't just draw random cards every time as you will get hosed without the wild cards as they are needed so badly for some routes and for tunnel flexibility.  The cards are bigger so my thumb doesn't get all cramped up.  Honestly why would I go back to the original after playing this?  Version 2.0 is much better!

RATING: 7
Ticket To Ride: Europe is another sequel to the antique Ticket To Ride. Developed and published later in 2005, this game can still be found on the shelf in every retailer and board game shop. I would say that this game is quite fun, with high replayability, but it would be boring after several repetitions. There are several expansions available and it would be beneficial to have them since the core game would not last long to sustain your fun. The pile of cards is huge and you actually spend most of your time shuffling it because it is very thick, indeed. This classic game is still something to be considered. Even I am considering to repurchase one.

:STAR: COMPLETE RATING:

[b]SCORE  CRITERIA       WEIGHTING       ------- STAR RATING SCALE -------[/b]

(4.0) FUN             (x15):         BORING :star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: REALLY FUN

(5.0) GAMEPLAY         (x5):       NO DEPTH :star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: LOT OF DEPTH (FOR THE WEIGHT)
(8.0) GAME FLOW        (x5):         FIDDLY :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: SILKY SMOOTH
(8.0) DOWNTIMES        (x2):         LOT OF :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: ZERO

(5.0) MECHANICS        (x2):         BORING :star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: INTERESTING / INNOVATIVE

(5.0) REPLAYABILITY    (x5):           ZERO :star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: INFINITE
(8.0) SCALABILITY      (x3):           POOR :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: GREAT AT ALL PLAYER COUNTS
(6.0) PORTABILITY      (x1):          BULKY :star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: SUPER EASY TO PLAY ANYWHERE

(8.0) SETUP TIME       (x2):           LONG :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: ZERO

(9.0) RULES COMPLEXITY (x1):        COMPLEX :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar: SIMPLE
[/c]
[b]TOTAL = 291.0/50 = 5.82[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Light-weight gateway game that is easy to teach, fast to set-up and fast to play with every family.


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- Gameplay can become somewhat repetitive after a few games.
-- Kind of expansive for what we get (yes there are tons of wagons, but for the number of hours played, it's not the greatest game).
-- Now, it's too lightweight for the two of us.


:arrowE: [b]OTHER GAME INFO:[/b]
[b]
Game Weight = 2.0/5
Release Date = 2005
Number of Player = 2-5
2-player length = 45-60 min.
Player Count Preference = Best at 3, recommended at 2, 3 and 5! :thumbsup::thumbsdown:
[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Primos
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
UPDATE: See my comments about Ticket to Ride. The "problems" in TtR that TtR:Europe is trying to "fix" are too fundamental, and TtR:E is trying to fix them with band-aids rather than going after the root of the problem. To quickly summarize: the problem is that the rewards for completing tickets are not properly scaled. Long routes are cheaper and easier to build, and also worth more points. A ticket that requires a tunnel or ferry to complete, which is much more costly to build than an equivalent route with no such required added costs, is worth the same points. The solution to TtR's problems is to fix the math so that risks are more fairly rewarded, not TtR:E's flurry of band-aids and chrome.
---
Basically, I think about the same of TtR:Europe as I do of TtR, with the exception that TtR:E has much, much superior components. The new additions make an attempt to address the significant balance issue of the original, that being the weakness of the tickets in general, and thus the overpowering strength of getting one of the few good, high-point ones. The attempt is largely unsuccessful, though, because it ignores the fundamental underlying problem: the points you get from a route are at best peripherally related to the difficulty of completing that route. So again, the most important skills here are a) drawing good tickets, and b) realizing that tickets are generally a sucker play.

My previous concerns about the pressure on the wild cards resulting in jammed-up games appears to have been overblown. TtR:E does have a bit more arbitrary screwage than TtR because of the 8-length generic-color tunnel route, which can have one player sitting on a huge percentage of one color for a good chunk of the game, thus screwing you if you really, really need that color. It's not a hugely significant factor, but it's frustrating when it occurs.

After a recent play of TtR:E I think I finally became disillusioned with this system. Sure, it works, it's simple, there is some tension in the choices, but the game is just so boring, so lacking in any excitement at all or interesting player interaction, and so lucky.

RATING: 7
Have the iOS app.

We played this game with Andrew's kids (6 and 4). It worked - the four-year-old got the game pretty quickly. The only downside was that the game took two hours - mostly because I was dragging it out to get the eight-train tunnel, instead of just ending the game.

I noticed they also took tickets a lot more often than I did - and only took one at a time. While one of the kids was choosing a ticket, the game effectively stopped. I started taking my turn while they were still deciding, and I think that sped up the game, too, but I could understand why the kids might need help choosing tickets.

I think that if Andrew and Christine play the game more, they can race to finish, and it'll be closer to the 60-minute playtime listed on the box.

RATING: 7
This is probably my least favorite version in the Ticket to Ride series but I will of course still play if asked. The reason why I don't like it as much as the others is that it's not good with 2 (and probably 3 too) players as it's just too hard to block because of the big map which isn't connected in a clever way, so you end up playing almost solitare games (okay, might be exaggerating a but, but that's how I feel compared to TtR USA for instance). Also, it's too easy to tell which long ticket a player has kept after just a few rounds and I think the stations detracts from the tension as you can often put a station down if you are blocked from where you need to go.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

My criterion for rating games


 http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder:  This game is very samey and feels the same every time I play it. The only differences are in the routes you draw.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions.  This game has quite a few meaningful decisions to be made. At the beginning, I like that this one has a guaranteed long route that you can choose to keep or not. Throughout the game which way to go on the map, which cards to take, when to draw tickets, and what tickets to keep make this one have a good bit more decision making that the original TTR.

3) Player interaction:  It does have a bit of interaction on the board as players try to avoid getting blocked and figure out work arounds when they do get blocked.

4) Components/artwork: Fantastic artwork, minis and cards. Days of wonder's usual great work.

5) Game length/complexity:  Great length of game and complexity. Easy to get players playing quick and still some good strategy and tactics to keep the game entertaining.



Bottom line: This game has some fun to it. I like it better than the original Ticket to ride as I feel it has more decisions in having the long ticket at the beginning. Also a little less luck as you could draw two long tickets in the original that are close together and then you have a big advantage.

RATING: 9
Love this after the first play - Was a big hit among all four first time players. Also easy to learn and teach, but there is a good depth here and a lot of thinking. I noted that it is difficult to plan ahead while other people are making their moves, since the face-up draw cards and available routes will sometimes change quickly. I spent a lot of my downtime studying the map to find alternative routes in case my best route was blocked. Similar game mechanic (color cards for claim management) to Web of Power and China, but plays very differently. 

[i]Quality complaints for Days of Wonder version:[/i]  Hollow plastic train pieces feel very cheap - wish they were better quality. The train piece colors aren't so great. The red we recieved is a bit more on the pink or salmon side of the red scale instead of a nice deep [-]fire truck[/-] caboose red. Storage cubby is beautifully roomy and DoW was thoughtful enough to include some spare train pieces of each color (seperately bundled) just in case some go missing.  Good quality cards, although I think it was a major error to make the train card backs blue - almost the same color blue as the blue train card faces, making it hard to spot blue cards that are flipped over in the deck.

RATING: 8

I like the mechanics, and the element of luck with the cards/routes. Would liked to have seen more long routes as after several plays you can guess the longer routes and maybe even try and block them if you're a nasty player.

Overall a great gateway game as has been said by many others, and it is easy to pick up and play in an hour or less.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
On the plus side, this game is easy to learn AND master. It is also fast-paced, since player turns are usually very short.

There is an element of luck and it is possible to ruin other players' game by picking on them, especially if you are able to determine what route a player is trying to complete.

This means you really need to make sure your player group does not contain both hardcore game-wreckers and people who like to be able to play their own game without too much negative interaction between players, or the game will become very frustrating and could easily result in 'softer' players thinking badly of it.

When playing with two players, there may be a LACK of interaction that makes the game a luck-fest since the player with the most appropriate destination cards will win, often with an impressive difference in scores.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I like this game over the original Ticket to Ride for two reasons:
1) Tunnels and Bridges make it worthwhile to spend a turn picking up a face-up locomotive.
2) The train stations make it easier for someone to recover from being cut off.  It will still cost them a turn, a card, and 4 victory points, but it's not game ending.

RATING: 7
A lot of fun--light enough to play most anytime with enough strategy to make it interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
People say this game is a great introduction to board gaming and they are right. I always loved the idea of board games and didn't realise that this whole other world of 'boutique' board games existed. I stumbled upon this when trying to buy mexican train dominoes online (in NZ) and after looking at reviews (on BGG) I bought it for my boyfriend for Christmas 2010. We played it and loved it.

We have played it with different groups of people (who aren't gamers) and it has gone down pretty well every time, and is often requested. Even my MUM loves this game.

I have played both Europe and USA and i prefer the variety of types of routes in Europe (tunnels, ferries, the long long train). USA is simpler to teach to new players (absence of tunnels and ferries and stations) but Europe is kinder to them (due to stations).

When we play Europe as a two player game, we remove the destination tickets that are on the eastern-most side of the board but we can build there if we want (but no tickets will go there). This makes the board much tighter and adds more tension to a two player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Once you learn the US version, you'll love this Europe version and stick with it instead. The big cards are easier to handle, and you are guaranteed a long ticket in the beginning instead of being stuck with dinky tickets. 
The tunnels add a cool wrinkle to the game, while the train stations virtually eliminate a lot of the blocking that frustrates both experienced and inexperienced gamers. Plus, there are significantly fewer long five and six long tracks, tracks that imbalance the game because they earn the player so many more points than smaller tracks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Ticket to Ride is a simple, accessible and tremendous amount of fun. Despite the semblance of such a dull theme, the satisfaction of secretly completing destinations and the imminent threat of opposing conductors taking your intended railway leads to many hi-jinx in the high-stakes laying of track across the old-timey European landscape.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Adds risk taking (tunnels cause routes to potentially cost more cards to complete and if you can't do it or refuse to complete the route you lose a turn), bail outs if you get blocked off (at a cost in victory points), and routes that require locomotives to complete (ferries) to the original Ticket to Ride: America.  The game plays a bit slower, but has more depth and variety to it than the original.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I'm not sure the tunnels are my favourite part of the game, but the stations and their interplay with the competitiveness element inherent in having fewer double routes makes the game more interesting than the original.

RATING: 9
Chyba najczęściej polecana gra na początek obok Catanu. Jest wystarczająco łatwa, żeby wprowadzić w nią nowych graczy w każdym wieku, zarówno dzieci jak i osoby starsze, tematyka jest na tyle uniwersalna, że nikt na wstępie nie odrzuca z tego powodu gry, zdobyła popularność na całym świecie, o czym świadczy liczba nowych map i dodatków. Rozgrywka jest prosta, w zależności od liczby graczy trwa 1-2 godziny, ale wymaga pewnej strategii odnośnie wyboru i realizacji tras, pojawia się nieco negatywnej interakcji w blokowaniu innym tras, którymi sami jedziemy, a także losowość w pociąganiu nowych kart. Idealna nowoczesna gra planszowa dla wprowadzenia nowych geeków, a doświadczeni gracze również nie będą się przy niej nudzić. Żeby zniwelować tłok na środku planszy fajnie sprawdzają się dworce.

RATING: 9
Hands down the better thought out game of the series.  Makes playing ticket to ride with max players an enjoyable venture, versus a gaming experience that results in people cursing their minds out.  The addition of the train stations allows casual and experienced gamer compete for the same routes, without feeling sour for being cut off and resulting in less abandoned games or conversions to chaotic players because of knowing they are out of the game.  Experienced gamers who like the original over this, are the same who memorize games & plays and play to dominate their opponents to prove some superiority complex.  This game is more balanced and a fun experience for all.

RATING: 7.83
9.10.11 My favorite version of TtR. This game plays very similar to the original but offers a few changes to keep things interesting. My favorite is Train Stations. I very rarely use these but in the odd chance you become blocked you can drop one of these stations to use another players track from that city to complete a ticket only (do no use for longest route). Next you have fairies and tunnels. Fairies require wilds and Tunnels might cost you 1-3 more of the color then expected. The only complaint is people don't know Europe as well as they know USA so they complain trying to find their cities.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
A lean, tight map that makes the U.S. map look like a walk in the park.  The lack of many double routes (and the added challenge of tunnels and ferries) makes it even tougher.

This is mitigated somewhat by the use of "stations" which allow you to ride on someone else's route that has been laid down.  But will someone actually cover the one you want?

Seems like this could be quite enjoyable with two players, but with four or more it's unnecessarily frustrating.  That being said, any Ticket to Ride map is always going to be something I'd like to play.

RATING: 8
A solid game. After playing USA online for months the Europe map takes some getting used to, but it is well balanced. The components are easy to handle and the cards have a nice weight to them.
Probably the best thing about this game is the fact that you can play is like USA by ignoring the ferries and tunnels, or you can add in those special routes and stations. Doing this you can take this game from a simple gateway game and let it grow with the players into something with more complexity.

RATING: 8
Production: Exceptional Days of Wonder production value, as always.  I like that the cards are full size.  Play: The map is more congested, with many routes that make a bend halfway through, which I find unattractive.  Because I'm not as familiar with European cities, I find the ticket destinations more difficult to locate than for the US version.  There are fewer long connections, which I miss from the original.  The four rules changes don't appeal to me.  Ensuring that each player is dealt a long route ticket is important for balance, but in the original I never felt that my bad luck with tickets was controlling my game.  The stations make the game slightly less cutthroat, and therefore less tense.  I find that tunnels and required locomotives make their respective routes too difficult. (3+2+3) (3 plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2012 holiday gift family

One of my two favourite "gateway" games to introduce people to boardgaming (along with Settlers of Catan), and a simple, yet brilliant casual game for more experienced gamers. 

There is a small degree of "screwage" possible when players deliberately block routes you might need. Simple to understand scoring mechanism though helps newbies understand the game, and players mentally keep track of what's going on.

Simpler than Alan R. Moon's other brilliant game, Airlines Europe, though with a focus on one's own routes (unlike the stock-driven Airlines Europe) I think the TtR series is the one that provides a bit more "fun" overall for a larger range of gamers.

It remains one of my favourite "entry" games, however, and has been played at least 20 times more than shown.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Divertidisimo, engancha
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
2-5 players, 45-60 minutes, light medium, trains

I've always enjoyed trains and games that involve trains and/or pick-up-and-deliver. So when I discovered Ticket to Ride a few years ago and learned how popular it was, I really wanted to get my hands on a copy.

TtR is a really fun game, easy to explain and easy to play. The game looks very appealing and the rules are quite simple. The game is very suitable for non-gamers as well and can be considered a so called gateway game. You can set up and explain the game in just a few minutes, so that's most welcome when playing with non-gamers.

I've played a dozen games with 2-5 players and all work quite well. As the map is rather large, 4-5 players is probably best, otherwise you will probably stay out of each others' way for the majority of the game. The game really shines when all players are actually competing to finish some central lines in order to complete their tickets. However, if someone beats you to it, you could still use the stations to "borrow" someone elses track, which makes TTR:Europe more forgiving than the original TTR. 

Although some people complain they make the game too easy, but I tend to disagree. They can in fact prevent someone from playing a lost game early on, so I think these really add something to the game.

There is a luck factor involved, as you're dependent on the cards you draw, but in the end strategy should pay out. Same goes for the tunnels, which are a unique feature of the European maps. When you want to complete a tunnel, then you have to draw 3 additional cards and if these match the colour of the tunnel, then you need to "pay" additional wagons (or locomotives) otherwise you can't complete the tunnel.

I'm a fan of this game and like to play this again anytime! Next to this version, I also own the TtR 10th Anniversary Edition of the original US map, the Dutch map, the Swiss map and the Indian map. Europe still is one of my favourites though and definitely a keeper in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent new version of Ticket to Ride.  Keeps the same great gameplay of the original while adding enough new things to keep it fresh.  The great emphasis on tickets instead of longer routes also makes the game more interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
It seemed to me, throughout the entire game, that there was very little interaction. The additions of train stations means you don't need to fear someone taking your desired route as much and though the game as a whole is an enjoyable shared activity, all the closed information and solo plans made it feel lacking in meaningful ways to interact.

There are obviously a lot of tactics to employ though, many of which I missed out on. For one, I kept drawing longer than I should have - I should have tried to just expand my route more (and maybe also prioritised grabbing the necessary routes a little higher - I didn't realise using train stations lost you 4 points excluding the points you'd gain for grabbing the route).

2008-05-28 5-> 7.1

I think the simplicity is great - keeping the game moving.

It's definitely possible to see where an opponent is heading and try to scupper their plans when competing. Though the stations make this less of a critical situation, the lost points (both for the station and for the potential points you would have gotten for the route) and card(s) keep it a factor.

There's a big advantage to being the player to cause the end of the game - or being able to use all your trains at the end - since unused trains are wasted points.

There's definitely less interaction than in some other games but there's enough going on to keep it interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Small changes from the base game, but a big improvement. I prefer the European board and find that tweaks to the gameplay all create a more interesting and balanced game.

Some people complain that stations "ruin" the game because blocking is less effective. Blocking is less effective, and can no longer cause someone to be out of the game very early on if they get blocked from key routes, but I don't consider that a bad thing. In most cases, using a station means you are giving up points and time, while failing to extend your route for the longest route award. That is usually punishment enough in my mind.

I consider this the best "main entry" for the Ticket to Ride series.

Expansions owned:
- Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 - Team Asia & Legendary Asia
- Europa 1912

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
To be perfectly honest, I thought I was "above" Ticket to Ride.  Gateway games are too just easy, too bland, and not as fun as their more complex brethren.

Then PhunkyMonkey had us play his 10th Anniversary Edition Ticket to Ride, and I was honestly surprised at how good of a time our group had--including me!  Sure, the game is simple, with very few things to do each turn, but it is in that simplicity where the enjoyment lies.  There is low stress when making decisions, yet the decisions you make are still important and have consequences.

Sometimes playing a game that is low stress and just fun is worth your time, too.

RATING: 8
This is perhaps my favorite iteration of the TtR franchise. More depth than TtR America, less fiddly bits than TtR Germany and a couple of good add-ons to extend its use-life.

I suppose that to date I've played this 200 times or more, and am happy to play more. 

It's very good for introducing non-gamers to the gaming universe, is liked by a great many people, and plays reasonably quickly. 

The strategic depth is not all that great. Nevertheless, it's a really fun game.

RATING: 7
Nice variant of the original game that fixes the long route issue from its parent game, and adds a couple of nice twists like tunnels and stations. Great for people who may be a little tired of the original.

However, I can understand the complaints regarding the tunnels for competitive players who enjoy blocking strategies. Here that doesn't really exist. Also, I think the one 8-length route that generates 21 points all by itself can be too crucial.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What I liked
* Easy to teach and play
* Appeals to gamers and non gamers
* Thought the theme would be dry, but enjoyed it
* Plays fast, little downtime
* The tunnels
* The map just feels more interesting than the USA map.
* Pieces come baged and with spare carrages!

What I didn't like
* Need to make sure the deck is VERY shuffled before starting each game.
* Game is all about efficiency, unfortunately luck plays a fairly big part in how efficiant you can be.

If experienced players are playing against beginners, they really should give some helpful advice about what to go for and strategy before the game starts otherwise there is a very big advantage to the experienced player.

* Some of the printing on the cards on my copy was dodgy :(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
You could call this a "definitive" edition for Ticket to Ride. It contains everything that the original contained (well, except the NA map, I guess), plus adds a few complicating factors- tunnels, ferries, and stations. The additions are much-welcomed, and make for a more varied playing experience. The components are great quality, and the board is beautiful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent sequel to the original. The stations and the new route layout are both welcome additions (although it is sometimes hard to find your potential destinations, if you are unfamiliar with European cities). I'm still undecided on what I think of the tunnels. I like the risk/reward element, but I haven't played this version enough yet to fully develop an opinion on this addition. It would have been nice if this map had just been included on the back of the original map like Power Grid did.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Different enough from its predecessor to warrant a purchase.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent improvement on the original. Tunnels and ferries add some extra gameplay and the stations are good escape for unfortunate play. I also like the re-emphasis on fulfilling tickets that comes from fewer long links.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Thumbs up. The stations shift the emphasis from claiming long connections to completing destination tickets. You're more likely to take a flyer on drawing tickets when stations are available to help you complete them. I prefer this way of playing, as there's too much card hoarding when players are going after the long connections. The stations also limit the effectiveness of blocking --- a good thing or a bad thing depending on your style of play (good for me).

Alas, not all the news is good. I don't appreciate the tunnels in this or in any other expansion. On balance, the game is maybe slightly better than the original.

BOUGHT WALMART AUG 2017
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[2011-07-28 Rating: n.a. -> 7]

Ticket to Ride (TtR) is a great game to introduce people to the world of gaming. The core mechanism of collecting sets of matching colored cards to build tracks on the map is not difficult to understand. The hidden points of the tickets keep everyone engaged in the game until the final scoring.
There is luck in the game and I guess TtR isn't a game that is enjoyed by heavy gamers. But I guess, that there's also some room for skillful play in TtR. 
All in all, I just like to play this TtR from time to time as it is fun to watch your railway network grow and screw the plans of the other players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players either draft rail car cards, play melds of these cards to connect cities together (and score points), or draw ticket cards (hidden agenda points).  Most points wins.  About 95% of the original game, with a few new rules for stations (use other players track [Transamerica]), tunnels (you may not build your track) and ferries (require locomotive cards).  Good points - looks great, you can play with the brain turned off and still win.  Bad points: still feels 30 minutes too long, too close to the original to warrant owning both, card stock is very thin.  Perhaps try the new rules in the parent game - very easy to do.  Will not be popular in Portugal ;-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I've only played this once, but based on my plays of Nordic Countries, I feel comfortable rating this one about the same.  I like learning the European cities, and I like the bright colours and attractive map.  There is also a fair amount of strategy in deciding what to pursue. The mechanics are intuitive and easy to teach, and I'm looking forward to introducing this one to my family.

Update: We never seem to play this, my partner is not a big fan because with 4 or 5 players there is too much downtime between turns, when the turns should be simple and quick. She likes Nordic Countries with less players better.  Up for trade now.

RATING: 7
Idea:
Connect your cities effectively by railtracks. Try to gather lines that overlap eachother.

Mechanism:
Draw connectable lines and connect them by drawing colored 'train' cards. You need certain amount of colors to build track between two cities. Score more points from cities that are far apart.

to who:
Easy to learn, somewhat amusing but suffers from fact that there arent enough randomness in the lines. Specially 'long lines' are way too predictable. This is classic though.

RATING: 8.5
Game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
TtR:E is in most respects a more-interesting and deeper version of Ticket to Ride. The stations mean arbitrary losses are less likely; the tunnels and ferries add additional considerations to train card acquisition; and players are guaranteed a long route and several short ones. It seems that the routes are more balanced over all, as well.

Here's the thing: Ticket to Ride has a serious problem in competitive play. Tickets aren't very valuable, and optimal play consists largely of playing long routes to end the game quickly. I'm insufficiently experienced with the European map to comment on whether the game "fixes" this, but my strong suspicion is that it doesn't.

Should this matter? I'm not sure. I know some would claim that this sort of problem doesn't matter; that a game has a way it should be played, and play outside of these bounds is the fault of the players, not of the game. It's a compelling view in some ways, but I find its interpretation impossible to pin down. Perhaps that's my fault, and not the fault of the viewpoint.

Ticket to Ride is a family game. It's not meant to be played optimally. One should play in the spirit of the thing, and one should recognize what that is. This spirit is maddeningly difficult to pin down, and unenforceable. I'm being a gamer, here, focusing on some kind of rule or clear method of enforcement. Perhaps, again, that's the wrong way to go about it.

How should I treat Ticket to Ride? I enjoy it as conventionally played just fine, but even ignoring potential exploits at higher levels of play, I couldn't say the game is much more than average. I still enjoy average games, and I enjoy the occasional round of Ticket to Ride: Europe. But that's really the most I can say.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
(Up from 6.5 base game)
Europe was the first expansion I got, and still one of the best.  Having stations in the game is an improvement, imo, as it gives you a way to recover from being blocked out of somewhere.  They're not free, and aren't something you want to be building if you can avoid it, but they are a good safety net.  
The separation between long and short routes is another welcome change.  No longer can someone draw NY-LA off the top when they already have a connection between Boston and San Diego.  All the tickets you draw later on are small to medium routes.  
Tunnels are a little more random than I'd like, but if you keep an extra wild back, you'll be fine most of the time.  But, there are still some times where you hit 3 matching cards and lose your turn.  The ferries also increase the value of wild cards, and make drawing them from the display more attractive. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Better than regular Ticket to Ride, but still would rather play another game.  Family really enjoys it!

RATING: 7

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
More wormy short ways to complete tickets. Less opportunities for one-move score bombs, added difficult-to-complete routes (tunnels and ferries), extra options to reroute around blockages (stations let you piggyback on another player's route, but at a cost in points).

I do like it a lot, but still like the original version a shade more..!

RATING: 7
This game is finding a nice spot in my collection as the definitive intro to boardgaming...or if someone isn't quite getting the rules of another game, we'll pull out Ticket to Ride.

I like the game, but if I'm with people who have played some other games I'll suggest another game, but I wouldn't turn down a game and don't get too upset when a newcomer isn't understanding a game and we end up playing this game.

Fun game and a 2 or 3 player game is nice, but once you get over 3 players the frantic feeling of losing your route really kicks in!

RATING: 4
Yawn fest. Rummy but where the sets you collect are rather dictated to you by objective cards. Consequently it becomes a game of risk assessment, priority assigning, and efficiency. I already work for a living, would rather do more interesting things when playing games. Theme has no connection to mechanics.
I think this game shows the division in what people are into gaming for. Some folks don't want to think very hard when gaming, they want to relax and engage with a simple puzzle, this game will be fun for them. For me, there isn't nearly enough going on.

Update: szerencse mindenképp: milyen utakat kapsz, de 5 fős játékban mind az 5-en száz fölött, és 4-en 115 pont fölött.
Továbbra is: nagyszerű jáétk

RATING: 8
I'm in the camp that doesn't mind conflicting additions to this expansion. It is both a more complex game (with the stations and use of mandatory wild cards)and more luck based (the tunnel draw) than the original. The reason I don't mind either of these additions is that they are thematically driven. 

Yes, TTR isn't the most thematic game in the world, but these additions give it that little nod towards theme that the original was lacking.

Tengo entendido que la versión de EE.UU. es más sesuda y tiene más pimienta. Pero ir construyendo líneas férreas en el viejo continente es una verdadera pasada!!!

RATING: 8
It's a good "gateway game" with easy-to-learn mechanics and light strategy. The downside is that after you've played it 10 - 15 times, you easily have many of the routes memorized. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played this game quite a number of times despite my number of plays on BBG due to online play included with Days of Wonders web access code.  The Original TtR is the perfect gateway game to get people who have only played Parker Bros./Milton Bradly games, into the vast world of board gaming.  However, I'm glad I started with this version as I find the original to be a little too simplistic and the components in the original needing an upgrade through USA 1910 expansion (ie larger sized cards) which would be an additional purchase. TTR:E has new game mechanisms as well as already including larger sized cards.  The only nitpick I can really say is that it's a lot harder to find the cities on the Europe map compared to USA and the cards don't really help you despite their images trying.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Juego sencillisimo y viciante. Es relativamente rápido (depende de lo pesados que sean los jugadores; pero aún así es rapidito).Muy indicado para novatos y para niños.
La versión "Europe" aporta más gracia al juego por el hecho de tener las estaciones, los ferrys y los túneles; además se puede jugar sin ellos con lo cual se queda igual que la versión "USA". La ampliaciuón "1910 USA" a mi juicio no aporta nada de nada.
Tenemos varias estrategias para intentar ganar: hacer mucho recorridos o hacer pocos y rellenar tramos largos que dan más puntuación; todo dependerá de los trayectos que te toquen en las cartas iniciales; es muy divertido fastidiar a los demás pero con las estaciones es más complicado. Quizá la mejor versión del juego la obtengamos con una sola estación o ninguna por jugador.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Rating based on - 75+ plays, 2 player[/b]
This is 4th game (and the first big box game) I bought when I got into hobby boardgaming a little over a year ago. It's a game with Europe...and trains! Yay! :) It is easy to learn, and a fun puzzle to play. The map is huge and after our first 'normal' plays, to mix it up we sometimes play with 10 extra trains, or a 'Ghost Train' variant that I made up where the Ghost Train tries to fulfil destination tickets of his own. It has stood the test of time and we plan on adding other maps to the mix for some variety. We have never used the stations. It seemed kinda pointless and clunky. Maybe something to add variety in the future.
[b]Status: KEEPER[/b]

What can you say that hasn't already been said about this amazing, ground-breaking game.

RATING: 9
The Europe map feels very different from the US map. Lots more shorter routes with very few longer (no 5-train, 2 6-train, 1 8-train). Tunnels and ferries only slightly change the feel but add more to the theme. Stations are the most significant change, eliminates most of the blocking aspects or adds a few points if you don't use them. I'm thinking I still prefer the US map by a hair.

RATING: 8
I like this one just as much as the base game.  The unfamiliar geography for U.S. gamers means it's tougher to bust this out with the more casual gamers who usually enjoy Ticket to Ride; the extra rules with tunnels and ferries also makes the game more complex.

So TtR Europe is really the gamer's version of the system, but it's still too light in some respects, so that might hurt the game overall.  Still, I like it a lot and really respect the game system and how it brings people into the hobby and is so enjoyable for newer gamers to sit down and play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ticket To Ride is a simple and quick game that is tactical, with a little "screw you" factor to keep it interesting.  While 2-player games of it have little involvement, 5 players still feels solitaire, although, available routes fill up quicker, so the tension of the game is sharper.  Although this feels light, there is an interesting luck management component using cards that keeps things interesting, and the board and theme is pretty (although gameplay has nothing to do with building and managing train-lines in any real sense.  It's practically an abstract card game). Balancing card gathering and line claiming also adds to the immediacy of each turn.  TtR is good for causal gamers and more advanced gamers who want to pull out something quick, pretty and generally fun. Though I still feel you need more luck at times than skill, which is disappointing. Which Destination cards can really decide your game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Simple, fun and challenging, a top-notch family game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I enjoy Ticket to Ride, so naturally find nothing wrong with it's successor.  With that said, I do prefer the original.  I don't believe the tunnels, or ferries offer anything of any real substance (it just prolongs obtaining cards making shorter routes more attractive - in a sense removing the decision), and I actually prefer the map of the original, even if I am European by birth right.  The American map, I find, lends itself to more interaction and screwage and therefore more fun.

UPDATE:  After quite a few additional plays of this I have to up my rating, as my opinion of TtR:Europe has  heightened with more familiarity.  I don't mind the tunnels, and think they actually can add to gameplay as they add a risk/reward element, but I am still not convinced about the ferries.  These routes can really slow ones progress, as they require locomotives.  Seems o.k. in theory, but in practice this can cause a headache.  Where once the occasional locomotive gave one the ability to replace a card that couldn't be drawn, the new rules now can constrain that flexibility and cause that dreaded feeling of "draw, draw, draw and hope or the best".  This is because, there is nothing here to substitute for the locomotive cards, so those going for ferry routes I feel are at a strong disadvantage to those without.  WIth that said, the Europe map is beginning to shine and with more plays, and knowledge of the routes the map can be delightfully cut throat.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is classic for a reason.  Easy mechanics and mild strategy combine to make for a quick, entertaining game.  Once you have sorted the longest routes, it becomes pretty obvious which one a particular player is shooting for, but given the incentive to complete multiple routes, defense is a dangerous proposition.  Generally good game, although I'm not sure how long it will last as a top choice in our house.

RATING: 6

UPDATE: I recently played TTR: the original again after a long hiatus.  I like the original better!   TTR:E adds complexity without really improving the overall experience.  The tunnels add a luck element that I don't particularly care for and the stations take some of the tension out of the route-blocking feature.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
The quintessential gateway game!
Less simplistic and random than its predecessor TtR, the Europe version is totally brilliant and addictive as hell. Everyone whom I taught the game to has enjoyed it very much and it is still the most requested one at my gaming nights. With the excellent expansion Europa 1912 the game acquires a bigger set of destination tickets (a whopping 101!!!) and, thanks to the Big Cities variant, overcomes its only limit: the lack of tension with 2-3 players. For me this is arguably the best version of TtR and an excellent game no-one should miss in their collection!

UPDATE: more than a year and 50 or something boardgames later, TtR:Europe(+Europa 1912) is still the most played game in my groups. It has showed an incredible staying power that many other boardgames (including some in the TtR family) don't have and everyone who tries it loves it at first sight. Magnificent!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Nice and complete game. For all. Some lucky components

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My second favourite version of TtR, I like that the stations allow for more ambitious tickets and the map is tight and has some interesting quirks. Nordic Countries is better, though.

I usually find TtR a bit stressful and aggravating, spending turn after turn trying to find just one specific card and never finding it before an opponent steals the route you were going for.

TtR is unique in the way it frustrate me. In a less luck-dependent euro game if an opponents blocks me, I can admit that they outplayed me and it adds tension without being frustrating. In TtR whenever anyone blocks me, regardless if they've clearly been playing better than me and planned it in advance, I still blame luck for not getting me the cards I needed 1 turn earlier. I recognise that luck isn't a huge factor in TtR and that the better player usually wins, but it just doesn't feel that way when playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a great family game, and a great choie for an intro game for non-gamers.  We've converted about a dozen people who were initially skeptical of "board game night" but now all they want to do is "play the trains game!"  

It's not complex, and not very deep, but it accept some strategy, especially in 3 and 4 player games.  As a 2 player it doesn't work quite so well.  My wife and I, when playing 2P, usually just work on our own tracks independent of one another and count up our points at the end.  The real fun comes with player interaction and conflict, so this is best played in small groups.

UPDATE: My wife and I seldom seek this game out except as a gateway for new people who are skeptical that they'll enjoy a boardgame.  Without fail, they love this game.  It's alright, but we feel like we've outgrown it.  We keep it just to see the joy in other people when we play it with them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
