RATING: 9
I own these physical versions of Ticket to Ride: Europe, India/Switzerland, and Africa.

I also play TtR on my phone (USA + 1910), and on Steam (USA + 1910 + Europe + Asia). 

My rating for Ticket to Ride as an entire entity is a 9 because it is a game I can be addicted to. The game is simple, but there is also a surprising amount of strategy to this game. I like the set collection mechanism, and the different rules depending on the map selected.

As for rating the individual maps, this is my current preference:
1. United States (w/or w/out 1910)
2. Europe
3. India
4. Asia
5. Africa
6. Switzerland

*I only log physical playthroughs of Ticket to Ride. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
More TTR
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very smooth and addictive game with nice theme.

Pros:
+ Fast and smooth game play, almost no downtime at all,
+ Rules are very easy to learn,
+ Nice theme,
+ Nice components - good art work,
+ Although some luck elements exist (card drafting), still game is strategic and fun as well,
+ You can always count all points at the end of game to be sure, if points, which got during the game, are correct.

Cons:
- Game rules are not so excellent made for playing with 2 players, because train cards do not circulate well enough (should be at least 7 face-up train cards for game with two) and the map is not filled enough to use other player's routes with stations,
- Card drafting makes some random in this game. Of course, you can always try to handle that, however random chance should be decreased more than it is in this game (by making more ticket cards and allowing players to take 5 tickets instead of 4 and still keep 2-5 tickets only at the beginning of game and of course allowing to use 7 face-up train cards, instead of 5),
- Card shuffling - the train cards should be shuffled very well and that's the job, one person should do while playing the game - to shuffle cards, because there are so many train cards and they should be mixed well. If you want to shuffle cards properly just when the train cards deck should refilled, then a downtime in game can happen, because cards ar many and shuffling them takes long time.

P.S.
My highest score currently is 170.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I enjoy all the Ticket to Ride games, and while there is much to enjoy in the European version, I think it's the weakest entry of the series.  Let me start with the bad and work toward the good.  The European board is less attractive than the U.S. map, with routes crammed into tight spaces at haphazard angles.  The tunnels are thematically appropriate, but I dislike what they do to the game; there is enough randomness and uncertainty already, and I don't see why we need another random element.  The ferries are also a hindrance to the game, encouraging players to robotically draw blindly off the top of the deck in hope of getting wild locomotives.  There are too few long tickets (only six!?!), forcing the play into stereotyped patterns.  Most significantly, the easy availability of the train stations deflates some of the tension over securing critical routes that made the first game so exciting.  I'm not saying I entirely dislike the stations, but their inclusion comes at a cost.  Initially I was also skeptical about the removal of the 6-train connections and the overall shift toward shorter connections.  The original Ticket to Ride's strength lies in its drama, and breaking it down into more incremental pieces leads to a less dramatic, more balanced game.  Alan Moon has a tendency to create games where you score zillions of times in little tiny amounts.  I think sometimes he goes overboard with this idea, since bigger chunks of scoring provide more pressure and drama, giving me the feeling that my next short-term goal is very important rather than just a minor matter.

The prevalence of shorter routes does shift the emphasis of the game nicely toward completing tickets and building an efficient network of tracks.  The original game was too often won by whichever player drew tickets that could be completed with chains of long, length 5 and 6 routes.  The European version is much more balanced in that regard.  It's still important to have some luck with drawing synergistic tickets, but now there's much more flexibility in route planning, and now all areas of the board are viable.  Another point in favor of the European version is the way that the stations make the 5-handed game less of a crapshoot.  The larger cards are of course a great improvement.  Finally, the finishing scores tend to be much closer in the European version; this is the flipside of the incremental-ism that I criticized earlier.  The choice then, is between a game that is tighter, more balanced, more varied (Europe) and a game that is more dramatic, more tense, more interactive, but is more prone to wild successes or catastrophic failures (USA/Canada).  I enjoy both games, but prefer the original by a large margin.  Ticket to Ride Europe may be a good choice for those who usually expect to play with the full table of five players; others should stick with the original.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 6.6
This is the first game, after Risk, Monopoly and cluedo that really introduced us to board gaming. And it's the one the missus likes to play the most - without having to twist her arm - so it tends to get played fairly regularly. It would also be the game I would pick most as a gateway game; because it was ours. There's something about this game. The balance of luck and skill is just right. The map is nice and so are the cards. Even the plastic trains look okay. Would love to just be able to trade cards though! It has to be one of the best family friendly games, even if a little blocking goes on occasionally, its all good fun - usually! It plays with 4 in around 45 minutes.

RATING: 7
Better than the original (America) map.  Not only is it bigger, but it adds complexity in the form of tunnels and train stations.  

Note: Thurn & Taxis has similar features (drawing cards, connecting cities, numerous map expansions) but is a more engaging game.  It isn't as popular here in the US because of the antiquated theme (the south German postal system, c. 1700s) and because it is more strategic.

The game is so simple, but it is just so much fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Sínen vagyunk
Vasút és társasjáték asszociációból kevés embernek nem a Ticket to Ride széria jut az eszébe. Ki az Egyesült Állomokat „sínesíti” be először, ki Európát, mégis a listák előkelőbb helyén az európai verzió áll.
De miért is? Amíg az Újvilágban egyik bevált taktika bizonyos útvonalak befoglalása és ezzel az érzékenyebb lelkű mozdonytulajdonosok „megbántása”, addig az Öreg Kontinens már más füstök fújnak.
Az alapvető játékmenet – vonatkártyát húzol, vasútvonalat építesz, menetvonalakat teljesítesz- nem változott, csak újdonságokkal bővült.
Egyrészt vannak olyan útvonalak, ahol kötelező mozdonyt, dzsókert letenned (4-5 főnél már komoly cél egy-egy mozdonykártya megszerzése). Másrészt az alagút építésekor kockázatot is vállalsz, amire vagy felkészülsz, vagy nem.
Harmadrészt, egyben legfontosabb változás, hogy megjelennek az állomások, amelyek segítségével egy-egy már befoglalt útvonalat tudsz felhasználni a kezedben lévő értékes menetvonalak teljesítéséhez. Összesen 3 állomás áll a rendelkezésedre ehhez. Elegáns módja a problémamegoldásnak.
Negatívumként talán csak a menetjegyek relatíve kevés számát tudom felhozni, de mindezen apróság ellenére egy nagyon jó játékról van szó, amely magyarul is elérhető.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
World's best gateway game.

D.A

Un euro clasico, de los facilitos del genero.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Even better than the original - Ticket to Ride - and that's a very good game.

POSTIVES

I like train games. 

It's visually appealing.

The Western side of the board is congested with lots of short routes. The Eastern side is sparser with longer routes. This contrast together with the unusual shape of Europe with its many peninsulars makes the map interesting. 

The tunnels, ferries and stations add an interesting dimension to the game. 

It is a good, light, fairly short family game. 

Although the rules are easy the tactics can be quite engrossing.

NEGATIVE POINT

The game has a lot of replay value. However there are only 6 possible long routes. It is difficult to win without achieving a long route. The lack of variety of long routes makes them a bit repetitive after a few plays although there are alternative ways of achieving the long routes. You could of course play it without the long route cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Classic Ticket To Ride, very similar to the U.S.A version with a few minor tweaks that allow this to be a 9.5 versus a 9. From a mechanics standpoint the tunnels and ferries introduce a slight change in strategy which i like, but the real gem here is the train stations which allow you to borrow a route to complete a destination for yourself. Outstanding fun.

Remove the stations for a really cut-throat version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A little more complex than original TtR, mmmm yes; a bit more challenging, maybe; do I recommend it? of course I do!

An excelent game, the addition of the stations and tunnels is great. They add a bit more of complexity to the game. Stations give you an opportunity for scoring tickets while tunnels may force you to spend max 3 extra cards.

Even the ticket cards have the position of where they are located in the map, sometimes you may spend a bit more time that you expected searching for the cities but it is part of the fun.

At the end of the game, you have to be careful of not completing your tickets because you may lose more points than the ones that you win.

-------------------------

Un poco más complejo que el TtR original, mmmm sí; un poco más desafiante, tal vez; ¿recomiendo el juego? ¡Definitivamente sí!

Un juego excelente, el hecho que hayan añadido las estaciones y los túneles lo hacen genial. Estas adiciones le añaden un poco más de complejidad. Las estaciones dan oportunidad de marcar los tickets que uno creía perdidos mientras que los túneles pueden forzarte a gastar hasta 3 cartas extra.

Un detalle es que a pesar que en las cartas de los tickets, vienen las ciudades en su ubicación exacta en el mapa, es probable que pierdas más tiempo del esperado buscando una determinada ciudad; sin embargo, es parte de la diversión.

Al final del juego tienes que tener cuidado de no completar los tickets ya que eso te puede llevar a perder más puntos de los que ganaste durante el juego.

RATING: 7
This is a game that doesn't really require a lot of thinking and has quite a bit of luck, but still, somehow, remains fun.  I think the fact it is quite short helps a lot.  How the other players play can affect your enjoyment quite a lot. If you are at a table where everyone just takes face down cards turn after turn until they all have a hand of 20 then it is pretty boring. If everyone grabs vital sections as soon as they can then the game can feel a bit more tense and interactive.

My main complaint is the luck of drawing new tickets.  It seems that at least one person will get lucky and draw already, or easily, completed tickets multiple times and score a massive amount.

RATING: 8
I have both this and the original TtR and can't decide which I like better. This board has MUCH better balanced game play out of the box: the routes are more evenly distributed and the train stations allow for greater chances to complete routes while ferry and tunnel routes add a new challenge twist. But the quirks of the original board are still fun to work with, too. I think this one works better out of the box without the addition of cards, though.

Overall, a great introduction to Euro gaming and "not Monopoly" gaming in general and still fun for all level of gamers I play with.

RATING: 8
A more interesting map than the US original with extra rules that throw some twists into the TTR mix, making decisions much more difficult. Long and short tickets help defray the luck element in what you get, but the restriction to 6 long means that where you're headed is guessable by those who know the game well. I'm less keen on the station mechanism, it's a soft 'last chance' to connect two cities, but it encourages the collection of an armful of cards, with less pressure to get tracks down. If I were buying today I'd choose this over the US map & rules, but they're too similar to justify owning both so I'll stick with my first purchase.

RATING: 8
Trains? Check. Lots of high quality game pieces? Check. A beautiful, sturdy game board? Check. More trains? CHECK! Ticket to Ride: Europe is loads of fun, whether with two players or more. I prefer it over the original version, though both are nearly identical in game play. The Europe version adds train stations to the mix, making the game that much more interesting. Seriously, you can't go wrong with Ticket to Ride. There's an equal balance between strategy and luck, but an experienced player can mitigate the risk of the latter. Punch your geek ticket and give it a ride!

RATING: 7
Something that seems to sit in the 'gateway game' category, with a theme that leaves some in my group cold. Enjoyable, although feels better played occasionally rather than repeatedly.

Like: The player interaction, both in cards taken and in competing for space on the board. The feeling of control, both in routes coming together/working around other players' routes, and in trying to get things complete when the end of the game is approaching.

Dislike: It feels a bit like the game is actually won or lost based on how complementary the initial route cards given out, and if any extra routes taken are easily added (or even already completed), rather than through deliberate player action - while it's certainly possible to lose from a good starting set of routes, it's incredibly difficult to imagine winning from a bad set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Purchased from DoW, November 2011.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First played December 17, 2008, Much like the USA game (different map; same rules), it's a quick learn (less than 5min) and quick play (~30min for 3 player). It does have a good balance of luck and strategy going for it, perhaps more luck. You build secret routes connecting two cities. Your opponents see your line forming, however they don't know your cities. You get more points the longer your route is between cities. Special bonus goes to the longest connected rail line. I'd recommend giving this a gameplay and consideration putting it into your rotation of games to play on a regular basis, however it may not be worth the fuss if you already have another map.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
It's OK as a family game, but played with gamers, the odds of winning depend on the extent to which your initial routes overlap. Knowing that makes it hard to take the game seriously: you deal out the route cards and see whether you're screwed or blessed, then spend an hour of gameplay confirming it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is my favourite TtR flavour to date.  The map is balanced very well - there are just enough alternative routes between cities to mean you aren't always locked out of the game, but without too many to completely remove the table-flipping cutthroat manoeuvres that are typical in this family of games.  I personally like the tunnel mechanic, some people don't but I think it adds a nice level of luck and some interesting decisions as to whether you'll try and hit the tunnels to make your route shorter but at higher risk of effectively missing turns by failing to place trains.

The stations mechanic is another interesting addition, which along with the tunnels make this much more family friendly than the original game.  The stations allow you to use your opponent's routes if you find yourself totally locked out of a city (maybe if you've been a bit slow or been concentrating on another part of the board), the routes used in this way don't contribute to your longest route bonus, but they are great for finishing your tickets.

I think I would always prefer to play this map over the original, and I also think it's much more family friendly as there's almost always a way to finish your tickets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Just a lovely and perfectly elegant game. 

The game is simple enough for anyone to pick up within minutes, but there is enough tactical decisions to be made during the game to keep it interesting over multiple plays. I love the Europe version for the added Depots, Tunnels and Ferry routes, as well as having a map that is more clustered and contested (all of these elements add more strategic flavor to the game without becoming fiddly in the slightest). The map is beautiful, and I love how it uses the native names for each locale (e.g. München, Roma, etc.). Playing brings back fond memories of traveling to all the various places shown in the game, and of course, the titular song gets stuck in my head (which for me is one of my favorite parts about playing it). 

One of the most pleasant experiences that can be had playing a game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.3
Very nice game, especially for new players as can be learned relatively quickly and is quite simple to begin with.

The Europe version adds more strategy and planning than the original US version, with both Ferry and tunnel routes.

There is still some chance wit drawing new destination tickets which can be a big swing (an already completed route versus an impossible to do one can be the difference between +13 and -8 to -13 points).

For this reason and the fact that its never a fully strategic game does cap my rating.

Overall its enjoyable, easy going and will play again and again.



(only started recording plays in 2017 as trying to play all owned games this year)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dice Tower's go-to gateway game involves collecting sets of cards followed by some conflict in competing to mark those sets out on the board. Especially good for kids as your goals are more or less predetermined, so the question becomes when should you do what. This can also be a problem though as the luck of the draw for missions will mean some people are more likely to win with less effort. Neutral theme should appeal to most people. I don't like the card hoarding aspect to this game as turns can become quite same-y while waiting for the right colored cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I bought this game to play on our camping trip (tradition to buy a new game each year) and we couldn't get enough of it.  It is super fun and can be played over and over. We have played it about 15 times and still love it. 

I have two daughters - 7 and 9. They both picked up the concept right away, the 7 year old even uses strategy.  We found they needed help the first handful of plays with their destinations and how to choose them wisely.

A few notes about the game itself:
~ The tunnels are stupid.  We don't play that rule - we treat tunnels as normal routes.
~ I wish there were a couple more long routes (only one 8 and two 6...I wish there were a couple 5 and 7 as well...)
~ Our first few plays we didn't use Stations (to ease into it) but realize they are a good element to the game.
~ We like the fact it's fairly easy to complete your destinations (not much "screwage") as it's better for the kids to handle.
~ I think any destination that involves a ferry or a tunnel should incur 1 bonus point per ferry/tunnel (as it's harder to complete)
~ I wish there were more long destinations...guess we gotta get the expansion.
~ The Olde English font and city names are kind of annoying but you get used to it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fixes one of the main problems with the original TtR: it is way too easy to get boned by your opponent blocking one of your routes, even if it was unintenional.  In TtR Europe, you can place a station at a city containing an opponent's route and use it as your own.  You have an incentive not to use the stations however, since they cost you four points at the end of the game.  Also it is nice that you and your opponents can only get a maximum of one long ticket, ever.  Superior in every way.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
(Based on 5+ online plays) Inferior to the original and not even close to as good as Marklin.  The addition of stations remove what little direct player interaction there was in the original to the detriment of the game.  The division of long routes and short routes is a good step, but is done better in Marklin where you can continue drawing long routes if you desire.  In my opinion the worst "innovation" of all is the tunnels which may randomly require you to play locomotives.  Blecch!  I'm glad I tried this online before buying.  

If you want a family game, get the original.  If you want a solid mid to light weight gamer's game get Marklin instead.  Thankfully, in Marklin the ability to block is not only back, but the direct interaction is increased with the competition for Passenger routes and the brinksmanship of waiting "one more turn" before activiting your Passenger. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Very hard to believe a game like this is sitting at rank 25?????

Quite a light game, yes a couple more things going on than the original but not anywhere near enough for any kind of strategy player. If you thought the first one was too light and you didn't like it this won't change your mind. Then there is the huge luck/random element that detracts from it coupled with spending most of your time just drawing cards and the tunnels are just silly. 

Playing with 2 like a lot of games is very dry and mechanical, playing with more there is at least a little tension. This would be a great intro game but it would never get suggested in my house or my group and Settlers is a far better game IMHO ergo better as an intro as well. Still for what it is it's OKAY but I think in some ways the original is better just because its shorter, why drag out a light game? Maybe a VERY occasional play but there are so many better games out there especially train games that this would never get purchased or suggested, using BGG rating scale this would be a 3 for me.

RATING: 3.5
2013-05-08

Initial Rating: 6.0 (November 2010)

I had fun the first couple of times I played Ticket to Ride: Europe ,  but this quickly became one of the games I try to avoid although I can be convinced to play it (if there is no other game available) :devil:.

As with the original game, I feel the game has obvious choices (always the same strategy), way too random for my liking (either you got the cards and tickets you need or you don`t) and also too light, very boring for me. In general I dislike games from Days of Wonders for those same reasons. This is a bit better than the original Ticket to Ride as you can play with stations that add a (tiny) layer of strategy.

This Europe edition adds more randomness due to the tunnels, it sucks.

On the other hand the game is perfect to play with the family or to introduce new gamers to the hobby. It also have gorgeous components.

Perhaps I will buy this to play with my family but don’t hold your breath. After playing this I have no desire to play any other game of this series (Märklin, Nordic Countries, Switzerland, the card game, etc.).

Current Rating: 3.5

RATING: 8
Good game. A little more complex than the base game ('though it's still pretty simple) but the additions improve it for me. 

Fewer longer routes mean that card-hogging (while still present) isn't as prevalent as in the base game where card hogging seems to be the best strategy. Ferries don't add much but the tunnels give a push your luck element and the stations offset blocking a little (it's easy to get blocked out in the base game).

Very good game for new gamers but still fun for experienced ones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a large improvement over TTR.  The new rules to ensure equal distribution of long routes, plus the overall increase in routes helps to really reduce the impact of luck.  

The stations are also a nice addition.  Ferries and tunnels are new, but just different, not necessarily better.

Overall, this is still on the lighter side of Eurogaming, but offers more than its predecessor.

RATING: 10
One of my latest new game, wonderfully produced with nice looking board, simple game mechnices but pack with lots of replayability value. Excellent gateway game for serious gamers as well as for family. As good as Carcassonne if not better. The main difference between this and Carcassonne is one has a nice map and the other don't. Carcassonne is a tile laying game, unique in its own way and this game is less random compare to Carcassonne and easier to strategize. I honestly consider it better than Ticket to Ride: US, the first series of this game.

RATING: 8.5
This I like so far very much. It is yet to be seen how well it plays with more than two players though. More comments when I have tried it with my children.

I have now played it several times both for real and on the internet. The internet version performs very well indeed.

I still find it very captivating ... I like that there are several different ways to win ... sometimes I go for a lot of tickets, at other times I try building the longest route and use my trains as fast as I can or just build as many long tracks as possible.

My son beat me yesterday (13. september 2005) and he was so happy ... especially since he knows I never let them win ... he beat me fair and square.

Sometimes I loose because I just can't get the right cards, but all in all it is a very good game indeed.

Scoring is a bit of a headache if you ever forget to take your points as you go, so pay attention!

RATING: 8
Ticket To Ride's move to Europe is notable for three things: cities as they would be spelled in their own country, long routes to aim for as well as smaller ones, and -- MOST importantly -- the tunnel mechanic which requires you have extra cards to pay the toll if the same colours come up. This latter part adds a level of challenge for some routes to make the game slightly harder but still easy fun for the whole family.

BIG PLUS: increased challenge without ruining the game
MINUS: some players don't get the names

Game rules are surprisingly easy and turns go quick but the game still manages to squeeze in a little depth. I'd say hop aboard and give this one a go.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This adds a little more strategy with the addition of tunnels and stations. Tunnels can require you to add additional cards depending on a random card draw. The stations allow you to use another player's track, but you lose some points. Other than that it is like the original. Start with route cards and figure out a path. Then collect the number of colored cards that match a track segment. Grey segments can allow any cards of the same color to be used. Engines are wild cards. Track segments score points with longer track segments scoring more points.  Complete the routes on the cards to score additional points. It is a nice family game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Cadeau Aure

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ticket To Ride: Europe is one of those games I often overlook amidst the myriad of deeper games.  Yet each time I return I am reminded of what drew me to the game in the first place and why it still stands tall as the champion of gateway games in my collection.  Few games create the same sense of urgency and tension that this game does. It is so simple and usually your goals are straight forward (that is once you have chosen your destination cards) yet there are moments of fierce anxiety as you race to complete a route before your opponents do.  There are few moments in gaming that compare to the excitement and satisfaction I gain from accomplishing a difficult mission or completing many routs in a game.  With all that being said, I wish that the board was better designed.  I think “America” has a better board, but I much prefer the ambiance of “Europe” and some of the added rout types.  There should be more 6-train routs and maybe even another 8-train route.  Still, this is a fantastic game that deserves high recognition in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I prefer the original (US map).

RATING: 7
Extremely fun.  Love being able to draw additional 'missions' at any point.  Love the tension of claiming the key routes you need in the early stages.  I think the tunnel concept in Europe is great as well. The game is easy to teach new players and about the right length.  The only thing I don't like is occasionally you can be desperately trying to finish your route and then someone ends the game by putting down their last few pieces.  The anguish of failing on your main mission and the knowledge that this means you have definitely lost creates a very bitter taste at the end of the game. This happens fairly infrequently though.

RATING: 8.5
It is hard to go wrong with any Ticket to Ride game. TTR: Europe plays almost like the USA version with just a few small rule changes to spice gameplay up a bit. If you are not familiar with the European cities, it can sometimes be a challenge to locate them, so let players new to the game sit so they can read the names more easily. Great gateway game for those new in the board-gaming world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
More complex than the TTR America game with the addition of ferries, tunnels and stations.  Depending on the game-geekery of the players, the added rules can be a bonus or a detriment.  Can be played without the tunnel or station rules for those who prefer a simpler version.  There are also fewer long routes on this densely-packed board -- mostly on the eastern (Russian) section of the map -- so certain strategy won't carry over well from the American game.  Paris has an amazing 10 routes entering it; is an essential hub.

Over all more of a challenge to score big than TTR America.  I consider the two games equally enjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I enjoy all the Ticket to Ride games, but frankly, my strategy on this version is still weak. The stations add an interesting element to the game, and help save your butt when someone blocks your track. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife and I really enjoy TTR-Europe.  I am a wargamer and she is a Scrabble player, so this is saying a lot.  Call me crazy but this game reminds me a little of Cribbage.  You need to decide whether you are going to focus on the 'ticket' points at the end, 'pegging' points by claiming longer routes or a combination of the two.  As in cribbage, if you can do both, you will win.

A 2 player game is fun and very easily plays in a half hour to forty five minutes.
3 and 4 players can also play quickly once the players are up to speed.  The game takes on a different dimension with more players and so far plays best with 4.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not sure it's better than ticket to ride, actually feel as though the USA theme works better so would probably slide that one just above this one, but it still is as good a 'first' board game as you can get. So easy to learn and teach and yet deep enough the better players will generally win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simple game that is easy to explain to non-boardgames players. For my taste it’s too long for such a light game, but it has the significant advantage that my partner will willingly play it. Definitely better with more players - on the one time I’ve played with 3, it felt like playing a tedious solo game of card collection. 

This is one game that isn’t over till it’s over - not only is there no player elimination, there is no telling who is winning until the final round, and even then it’s not obvious until the scores are in. The tension comes from a tactical level - trying to guess where other players need to place pieces, and trying to place yours first. 

The strategy, such as it is, comes in a careful selection of routes at the start of the game, and a decision about how to make sure that potential chokepoints won’t make your life difficult near the end. Stations tend to make those chokepoints less dramatic, hence allowing some of the steam out of the game.

Well before the end of the game, you will know whether it is still possible for you to complete your routes, simply by looking at the number of carriages that remain in your hand.

Tunnels add a little excitement, but otherwise, this is a game that is made up of a series of little triumphs as you add yet another little link in a chain. If that is what rolls your dice, then hey, who am I to knock a solid, yet rather less than stimulating, game?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This may be the game I've played more than any other game out there. It's elegant, somewhat easy to learn, turns are brisk (so there's very little downtime) and it plays as a multiplayer solitaire with just a touch of rivalry that makes the game a little more spicy than it would otherwise be. This means players truly feel in control of their own destiny rather than that they are subject to the tides of whoever is on their left and right. This is less true by adding more players - with 2 players virtually never interact with each other, with 3 or 4 this plays best, and with 5 the game is too cluttered. 

Despite the lack of language dependence players can and _will_ have problems with the geography. TTR: Europe chose to use (some) local names instead of their Anglicized variants. For example, on the gameboard and cards Rome is "Roma" and Copenhagn is Køvnhagn. If you're playing with people whose knowledge of European geography isn't excellent there will be some confusion and lost gametime - and even some tactical mistakes - when one mistakes Smyrna for Smolensk or Sochi. But hey, with repeated plays, one can even learn some geography from playing this game! :)  

Please note: unless you have a ton of money there are a lot of variants out there that are totally unnecessary. For example, TTR and TTR: Europe are the same game with a different board ... which means, if you buy both, you're essentially getting duplicate, unnecessary bits with a different board. $50 is a lot of money for what amounts to ultimately just a new board (unless you're an Age of Steam addict or something).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 7
One of the weakest in a set of fantastic games.  BGG'ers seem to laud the extra rules in this game.  For many of them, more complicated seems strictly better, but I find many of the rules detract from the play, with the tunnels adding randomness and especially the stations just seem to sap the tension out of blocking other players, since they can pretty much always make the connection with a station.  Also, the map looks more jumbled compared to the USA map.  It's nice that this game comes with bigger cards, but I still prefer the original USA version of this game for the streamlined play and greater tension.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is probably the best Ticket to Ride game. And the outcome is more likely to be skill-based than with regular TTR.

The ferries are cool because the increase the value of locomotive cards, which in turn increases the value of taking face-down draws. This makes your drawing decisions a little more interesting.

The tunnels tend to mitigate the advantage of drawing many overlapping tickets, since these overlapping tickets will be likely to pass through the central tunnel-infested regions. However, they also inject a hearty dose of randomness into the game which I don't think is really needed.

The stations are great. The best thing about them is that they allow you to really live on the edge of the knife with your ticket draws, which makes the game more fun.

Having all the tickets be 12 points or under, except for a single long ticket you get at the start of the game, is another change for the better. Regular TTR does suffer from some insanely lucky ticket draws you can make.

>20 plays counting F2F only.  Hundreds counting on-line, PC and xbox.

RATING: 7
As others have noted: nice gateway game. Nice game overall, but not my favourite.

UPDATE: Actually, this game has grown upon me. It is sometimes quite tense, with real turn angst. Less so when played two-player, though. Still works very well in that configuration. Should benefit from more tickets, and the long ones especially sort of railroad (no pun intended) your strategy. 

We play two-player games without the long tickets, which works well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This game has quickly become our favorite game.  It got 3 plays in the first few days after we opened it and my wife is the type who doesn't usually like to play the same game multiple times in a row.

It was a tough decision for me to pick this game or the original, but after playing Europe and seeing how the new features (tunnels, ferries, and stations) play in the game I'm glad we got this one.  It seems like a step forward for the same price as the original.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A Ticket to Ride variant that stays very close to the original and shares many of it's strengths. Along with some other small tweaks, this version introduces stations (3 per player) which a player can use to share a link belonging to another player for the purposes of completing destination tickets. This is nice since it reduces the potential brutality of getting totally blocked out of a huge destination ticket without completely eliminating the tension that comes from trying to avoid being blocked (since it costs 4 points and a turn to play a station and also because the borrowed link does not contribute towards the longest train bonus).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The weakest of the three sets for me. The Stations help people who like lower conflict, and the tunnel rules still confuse a lot of people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride Europe is a solid re-implementation of the original. Most of the changes of this one are oriented to reduce luck, so that skill is more important. It makes the game less cutthroat too, as blocking someone's main route isn't nearly as devastating as in TTR.

What I like the most are the destination tickets: having lucky draws is possible, but I still have to see a win solely based on having luck with the first draw. This is mainly due to the fact all players get a single long route destination ticket, as well as two route short destinations. No more a single player will draw a killer combination of objectives right from the start.

Aside from the obvious geographical changes, the map has also been optimized: there fewer long routes, so it's primordial that you use them wisely and try to go through them whenever you can, as they are worth more points and consume less actions than the shorter ones. The centre of Europe is cluttered with short routes, which makes blocking almost impossible, but if you just build there you will find that, even though you have all your objectives accomplished, you won't have gained much points through route building. The tunnels and ferries are not particularly relevant, as while not obtrusive, they neither increase the game's depth.

Last but not least, the train stations. They do make the game friendlier, as they allow you to use another player's route, but players should avoid using them. The three point penalty you get for placing them, not to mention the consumed action, means placing stations has a considerable opportunity cost.

All things considered, TTR:Europe reduces luck factor dramatically, but also reduces direct interaction, for better or for worse, and has a bunch of weird rules which can confuse total newbies. Still, both titles are great gateways.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

Bardzo proste zasady, świetnie wydana. Cenie sobie w tej grze szybkość z jaką potrafi wciągnąć nowych graczy w myślenie, kombinowanie i zaangażowanie się w rozgrywkę. Choć jest to tytuł typowo familijny to doświadczony gracz ma jednak sporą przewagę z mniej doświadczonymi i zazwyczaj będzie zwyciężał. Pomimo tego duch rywalizacji jest obecny do końca.

Obecnie rzadko ląduje u nas na stole. Jednak jak przyjdzie zagrać z nowymi osobami gra się nadal przyjemnie.

RATING: 6
This version of the game nearly solves the "long route" problem of its predecessor; however, the game desperately needs more long routes from which to choose at the beginning of the game.  I'm quite ambivalent about tunnels mainly because the short routes already have a built-in penalty:  points.  They're fine for longer routes (4+), though.  Stations serve to counter the lack of double routes and relieve pressure when the board gets crowded, although I'm not sure their use in this game is the ideal.  Still the TTR games continue to be enjoyable and I'm always up for playing them.

RATING: 7.5
[2007.Jun.11] An excellent introduction into the world of Euro games. With a high quality production by Days of Wonder, this Alan R. Moon train game builds on the success of the Ticket to Ride franchise. The addition of tunnels, ferries, and optional long-routes only enhances the TtR experience. Played on a beautifully rendered map of old Europe, this game is a breeze to learn.  Whether playing with Euro novices for their first game or taking a break from one of your brain burners, Ticket to Ride Europe is staple that should be present in everyone's game collection.

[2016.Feb.2] Not a gamers' game, but it's still a family favorite nonetheless.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite boards. I hate the 6-Route necessity of the original. I hate how important it is to have West-East routes, especially if you aren't dealt a good one at the beginning of the game. I hate how many rounds are spent with people just drawing, drawing, drawing...

Europe, on the other hand, has a bunch of short routes, so people are laying down routes more often. I love having one long route only. Someone having two long routes that overlap in the original can be a killer. I don't play with the Stations, but I think they are a great addition when playing with kids. I let them use Stations and the adults are forced to live without. Unfortunately, this one suffers from having too few routes - like the original - so you annoyingly have to buy the too-expensive 1912 "expansion". That brings down my score.

RATING: 9
Ticket to Ride: Europe takes you on a new train adventure across Europe. From Edinburgh to Constantinople and from Lisbon to Moscow, you'll visit great cities of turn-of-the-century Europe. More than just a new map, Ticket to Ride: Europe features brand new gameplay elements including Tunnels, Ferries, and Train Stations. The game also includes larger format cards and Train Station game pieces.

Like the original Ticket to Ride, the game remains elegantly simple, can be learned in 5 minutes, and appeals to both families and experienced gamers. Ticket to Ride: Europe is a complete, new game and does not require the original version.

RATING: 7
I like this a bit more and differently than original T2R.  I really like the train stations, ferries, and the limited/balanced stack of "Long" Destination Tickets ideas.  I'm not really sure of a few of the tunnels.  Perhaps a modification of only 2 cards flipped for 2-segment tunnels, or that a penalty cannot be more than half the length of tunnel (rounded up), might lessen potentially severe penalies.  But this is really a VERY minor thing and I'm not fully convinced any change is required so I'm perfectly fond of playing this most of the time versus original T2R USA. There is definitely more tactical tension on this map, and stations are a very good backup plan to have or to use with your primary strategy if you know fairly certain that someone will have a link that you could use.  With 5 players, someone's major plans probably will get ruined (and might suffer penalty tickets).  Will it be you...??

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Nagyon könnyen megtanulható játék, amit ketten is lehet játszani, de három vagy négy fő esetén jobban kiteljesedhet (öt játékos viszont már szerintem túl sok lehet). A játék helyigénye nagy, mert hatalmas a tábla, és mellette még kell hely a kártyáknak is, meg játékosonként egy nagy halom bábuknak.
A játék attól izgalmas, hogy folyamatosan döntési helyzetek elé állít:
1. Mely városok közé próbáljak utat építeni, azaz mennyit merjek kockáztatni? Ha nem sikerül a játék végéig teljesíteni a vállalt útvonalakat, súlyos mínusz pontok járnak érte.
2. Ha cselekvésként laphúzást választok, mely lapokat húzzam fel? Van, hogy egyértelmű, hogy mit érdemes választani, de van, hogy nem, hanem kicsit hosszabb távon kell előre tervezni, és annak megfelelően választani.
3. Mely részútvonalat próbáljam épp felépíteni? Érdemes figyelni a többi játékost, hogy merre építkezik, és ha számomra fontos útvonalak felé, akkor azokat meg kell próbálni lefoglalni előlük. Vagy úgy építkezni, hogy ha nekem nagyjából hasonlóan jó két útvonal is, akkor a többi játékosnak minél inkább keresztbe tegyek. Persze, éppen ezek miatt arra is érdemes figyelni, hogy ne lehessen könnyen kideríteni, mely városokat is próbálok összekötni, így ne tudják ezt a többiek megnehezíteni.
4. Figyelni kell arra is, hogy nagyjából mennyi van még hátra a játékból, és ennek megfelelően kell próbálni haladni és útvonalakat elvállalni.

A játék amúgy meglehetősen kiegyenlített, alig néhány pont különbséggel végeznek a játékosok, hisz mindenki nagyjából hasonló mértékben tud pontokat szerezni körről körre.
Jó játék, érdemes mindenkinek kipróbálni, a legtöbb embernek tetszeni fog.

RATING: 10

It feels hard to know how to play counter strategies but I think this emerges with more plays. If I hadn't already bought it I'd go for the gorgeous deluxe edition.

RATING: 8.5
Love this game! It doesn't take too long to learn how to play this game, yet there's some strategy to it.  A great family game for sure!  I think Ticket to Ride Europe is better than Ticket to Ride America as there is more clustering around certain areas and more competition for the same routes.  I think the whole layout is more enjoyable and like the added element of the stations which add more strategy and help to alleviate the lack of alternate routes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(Technically not my game, but my parents own it.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Other than [GAMEID=822], one of the big gateway games praised here is [GAMEID=9209].  We eventually went for [GAMEID=14996], mainly because the map seemed more exotic and attractive than the USA map.  This was a huge hit from the first time we played it, and we played it over and over again even with just the two of us.  We really liked games where we build things, whether it's cities in [GAMEID=822] or train routes here.  The route connection gameplay is incredibly intuitive and we've had lots of luck teaching this game to non-gamers.

When compared to the original, we found the Europe map to be more balanced.  We also found that the stations lessened the sting of getting blocked---you're at a disadvantage, but the penalty isn't as harsh.  We didn't mind the tunnels, and they gave us an added touch of "pressing your luck". The biggest problem with the Europe version is that there are only 6 long tickets that you distribute at the beginning the game.  It quickly becomes easy to memorize them and immediately know where each player is going.  The solution?  We play this [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/144998]variant[/url] where we toss out the long tickets and draw only short tickets.  This makes the game much more exciting, since you never know where the other player is going or where the hotspots on the map will be.  It's also more strategic in choosing tickets since it's more difficult to plan your longest route.  Although most Ticket to Ride games are fun with lots of players, this variant gave much more life to the game, especially with only two players.

Session Reports:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/281182]First Time Live in Months, or CURSE YOU TTR:ONLINE!!![/url]

RATING: 9
Before Game
Experienced TtR Player: "Ive played the American version loads I will thrash you all"
Girlfriend: "Whats this rainbow coloured card"
Me: "At last I get to play TtRE!!!"

During game
Laughter, smiles, some tension, a lot of thinking, some good fortune, some bad fortune, time goes very quickly ...

After game
Experienced TtR player - 3rd position - "It does play slightly differently ..."
Girlfriend - 1st position - "That was great can we play again"
Me - 2nd position - "At last Ive played TtRE"

Conclusion - fantastic stand-alone game, perfect weight to encourage the un-initiated into the hobby and enough meat for the experienced gamer to get their teeth into.  A game for everyones collection.

RATING: 3.5
I said this about Ticket to Ride: "I just can't get into this game. At all. I want to like it, but choices are limited, luck can make or break a route, and memorizing the routes is a huge advantage but not one that's satisfying or easily equalized, and strategically blocking routes is rough on non-gamers. It's not meaty enough to be a good gamer game, and isn't as good as Settlers of Carcassonne as a gateway game." This version does nothing to change my opinion (while the stations make it easier on new players, they also add more slop to the mix). Meh.

RATING: 5
[2005] A distraction from the original, not necessary. Force-fit some new mechanics, blech. The new mechanics are not appreciated by us, and makes it feel that it was done to make the (broken?) map work. Drawing cards for the tunnels, the stations, ugh. Did I say 'blech' ?

I'd rate this lower, but it's a TTR, and I'd play this if necessary and asked to play.

...but... After playing Switzerland and enjoying that one, we now appreciate the Tunnel drawing mechanism much more, and will give this another go.

[2012] Have played a bunch since then. It is better, but am annoyed by the poor graphics on the cards which don't match the map so the rating does not change, still a 5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very nice game and very easy to learn. In 5-10 min the rules are clear even for a first time board player. Also because of the easy game-play it will be loved by all the members of the family. It does involve some strategy but nothing very complex. I recommend this game to introduce a new board player to board gaming. Also it should be very appreciated by hardcore gamers.

Advantages:
- very easy to learn
- very fun to play for beginners and experienced players
- high quality components
- lots of decisions to make
- high reply-ability
- good player interaction

Disadvantages:
- if a players big track is far from others it will have an advantage but less player interaction
- not very in deep
- not many strategies

For my part I think the station are a good addition. They cost you cards and a turn. So they are quite pricy but they remove some of tension while removing thr blocking strategy. It's a good trade off.

RATING: 8
Same as Ticket to Ride but with a Europe map and the concept of stations, tunnels and ferries.  Stations allow you to connect to cities where you have been cutoff.  It is a friendlier version of Ticket to Ride.  Ferries need a certain minimum number of locomotives.  Tunnels force you to have extra cards in that color on hand because if you flip three cards and they match the color of the route you have to add a card for each one that matches.  

I actually like it a bit better and it is much more kid friendly.

RATING: 4.5
Very similar to the original TTR, but the tunnels and ferries are a cool edition.  Much welcome is the fix to the random long haul route problem: everyone gets one opportunity at a long route as game set up.

With two players the switch houses should be left out of the game.  Probably better used in games with more players?  Frankly, I think the game is too "open", and is far more fun with opponents fighting over conflicting routes making TTR something other than a rummy set collection game...for that reason, I am not a fan of the switch house.  It seems tacked on for those who did not like even a little conflict or tension in the game. 

I think I would rate this higher with more players, much like the original.  Thumbs down on the switch houses.  If playing with switch houses, I'd rate this a 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Seems to be the best TTR of the lot.

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/442458/ticket-to-ride-europe-as-part-of-the-ticket-to-rid

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/438673/ticket-to-ride-europe-vs-the-original-ticket-to-ri

That being said, many consider the game to be TOO easy-going without enough meat and therefore, while a negative for seasoned players, it seems to be a very big positive for playing with newcomers, non-gamers, younger folks, and folks who just don't seem to enjoy (at all) the competitive strategic nature of such a game.
See: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/675645/why-i-would-never-recommend-ticket-to-ride-europe

That being said, some seasoned TTR players tend to enjoy Europe more b/c of the tunnels and ferries.

RATING: 7
Excellent gateway game - easy rules, fun and thematic components, good mix of skill and luck. TtR:Europe adds some nice twists to basic TtR and has a way to avoid getting a vital route snatched away from you. For this reason I chose the Europe version for my non-aggressive family.

RATING: 7.5
Why aren't the stations in USA?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun, light game which plays in a reasonable amount of time for its category. There's definitely a significant luck factor in several parts of the game (drawing objectives, drawing train cards, the tunnels) but I don't find this to detract from the game. Certainly a good entry in the "filler game" category, its simplicity and low amount of screwage factor (at least with 4 players) makes it a very good choice for family/non-gamers nights.
It is also worth noting that the number of players has a significant impact on gameplay; 2-player games are more strategic and tightly knit, while 4-players are more luck-based and somewhat easy-going. For a nice "screw you!" atmosphere, try the 3-player version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Simple abstract game. There's some strategy but luck has an important role. More players make it more chaotic. Fast paced. Fine quality of bits.
It has a few extra rules to improve it (some are fine, like the new initial tickets, while some simply add randomness, like tunnels).
The map has more (and shorter) routes to  encourage playing more than hoarding.
Overall, slightly better than the original.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
With two people playing constructively (i.e. not going out of their way to stuff their opponent and aiming to fulfil as many tickets as possible) TtR:E is a bit underwhelming. Both games were very close (within 10 out of c100) but lacked the true nastiness of many other route-building games.

I suspect, however, that there may be an alternative strategy in which you take the minimum allowable number of tickets (two), learn the possible routes and then go all out to stuff your opponent. Each unfulfiled route counts double against the owning player so not completing a (say) 20 point long route would almost certainly prove fatal in a game that is otherwise very well balanced.

I'll re-rate after I've played with more and/or nastier opponents.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket to Ride: Europe was the third game that was added to my collection - my wife got it for me as a birthday present after my brother-in-law got Ticket to Ride USA - naturally Europe seemed a fit since I had lived there abroad for an entire year.

Like Ticket to Ride USA, this is a fun game - although it still gets me how Days of Wonder is so keen to squeeze every possible dollar out of the franchise that it won't release copies of the game with multiple game board maps (the way Power Grid does).  It's easy to teach and learn and decently fast paced (unless you are my brother-in-law Jim, who can make any turn last 30 minutes!!).

Europe is not a mere clone of Ticket USA, also adding Tunnels, Ferries, and Stations.  The Ferries don't add much but the Tunnels greatly impact strategy and the Stations add another element of choice in tactics.  I disagree with other commentators on here that think the Stations were an unnecessary addition.  Unlike Ticket USA, which is a much more spacious map with multiple ways (for the most part) to get to different locales, in Ticket Europe things are much more condensed and claustrophobic.  The Stations are important in balancing out the cramped conditions of the board.  Plus, it's not like they are a free pass - you are still giving up 4 victory points for each Station used.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The underground lines just make it more random.  Bleh.  And the long/short separation in the tickets is a good thing.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I'm not sure why I like the original version better than T2R:E. It could be that T2R:E is a 'nicer' version of the original as it's a lot harder to NOT make your routes. It could also be that I don't care for the map as much as the american verson. Or maybe it's the new rules that change the game for the worse in my opinion. Whatever it is, we'll play T2R ten times as much as we do T2R:E.

On the positive side, the larger cards a a big improvement over the small decks in the original - easier to hold, easier to see, easier to shuffle! I also like the segregation of the routes into long and short ones, but I don't care for the uniform way they get dealt out at the beginning of the game. I miss having the opportunity to draw a long route late in the game and having to agonize over taking the risk to go for it and keep it or pass it up as it's too risky and late in the game. 

T2R:E is definately more balanced, more friendly and more polished. Unfortunately, it is also less fun.

RATING: 8
Build railway routes through Europe in order to connect up the cities on your several (secret) destination cards. To build railways you must first collect cards of the colours of the routes you want to build. How the destination cards work together, the myriad route connections, the beautiful map, and the interaction with the other players makes this a cool game. But very tense.

RATING: 6
Ticket to Ride: Europe is my first experience with the series.  It is a simple card drafting Eurogame that would be a good starter to bring people out of the classic game market of Monopoly and into the new generation of board games.  It is light enough to play with ages down to seven and has wisps of strategy that would be good for the elder gamer.  Ticket to Ride does not give me that feeling of re-playability as with other games due to its length, non overly engaging theme, and elementariness.

RATING: 7.5
The train stations are a much appreciated addition to the game.  Also, the implementation of ferries and tunnels leads to people actually targeting locomotives;I have rarely seen in that in the original.

The only small gripes I would have for this version is that the colors are not as balanced in this version as they were in the original.  However, Europe does a better job of incorporating the grey lines so it makes up for it.

EDIT: Europe is a much more strategic map than the original Ticket to Ride.  If you are looking to play a more difficult TTR then you may want to check this out.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
Better than the original Ticket to Ride. Now there's a reason to specifically aim for wild cards, and if you get blocked out, it's not immediately the end of the world. RATING: 10
Best game of 2005 and one of my all-time favorites.
Updated version of the ultimate modern boardgame. Boardgame perfection really. This is bit more friendly map than USA TTR and thus better suited for family gaming. Sadly the tunnel rules add some complexity so in the end it's hard to say which one is the definite family game. I would still say Europe. Other than tunnels all the good things of the original apply to Europe aswell. Despite the slight increase in complexity, I think tunnels are nice addition too as they increase the exictment of  the game and add lots of tense moments when everyones eyes are on the card flipper. Europa 1912 is recommended if you plan to play a lot (cards of it anyway, the warehouses and depots are questionable). This simply the BEST game. It brings non-gamers and gamers together in unique way.

2-Player Comment:
* I love all Ticket to Ride maps as 2p, it's the game I play most often with my wife. 

Expansions:
+Ticket to Ride: Europa 1912 

I also own Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries, USA and Märklin versions. 
Map expansions listed under TTR: USA.

RATING: 7
This is a classic game that's starting to garner some "elitist sneering" - unwarranted in my opinion. It's a great gateway game, who hasn't played rummy-style games even if they haven't played hobby games? It's accessible, can be played by those new to the hobby and has some depth for gamers who play it sufficiently to learn routes and therefore strategy/tactics. There's also some expansions (notably the [gameid=182078] and [gameid=53383]) and some alternative games (e.g. [gameid=31627] that help manage other player counts)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good entry level stratgey game that provides enough depth for experienced gamers.
Players collect train cards that are used to claim train routes. Claimed routes cannot be used by other players and points are awarded for claiming routes and linking cities shown on their randomly assigned tickets.
An excellent introduction boardgame with reasonably simple rules. Adds rules for using a cliamed route, tunnles and ferries that are not in the base game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Trains + Set collection + Connect the Dots

This game is the one I recommend to anyone looking to begin exploring the world of modern boardgames (with Carcassonne a close second).

Simple to teach, great presentation, a good level of  depth, a nice range of strategies.  Each game will play differently.

Recommend it over Ticket to Ride America due to stations meaning players are less likely to be able to shut people out of the board, as it is possible to piggy back on other player's routes to help complete one's tickets.

The tunnelling mechanic adds a luck element that creates a bit of fun and suspense.  A great way to learn about European geography.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
A step back from the original in my opinion. The stations remove the incentive to block and the tunnels and gray routes with wild cards encourage drawing from the deck rather than from the face up cards. This is a bad thing because one of the best things about TtR is the ruthless efficiency with which you must select your cards. Not so in Europe, just keep grabbing from the deck and you'll get what you need. Yawn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
TTR and all its variants are just good games. “real” gamers like to trash these as not deep enough, or too much luck, but these are people that forgot what fun is. Also, they don’t understand how playing with randomness is actually depth but to each his own. 

Anyway, I like this variant because of the addition of the rule tweaks: mandatory use of engines in some spots, tunnel routes, ability to station. The board plays differently (not so many 6 places) yet because the main mechanics are the same it can be taught quickly. And like the base game the board, components and rulebook are nice. 

The theme fits well of course and I like trains, so there you are.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
It fixes many small issues of one of my favourite games (Ticket to Ride), which I rate a 8.5
In particular small cards, mean blocking techinques, excessive luck in the draft of the routes, scarce use of the jokers.....

However I think that the added rules make it more difficult to explain it to newbies. TtR is really straightforward, while TtR Europe isn't if you haven't played its "brother".
At the same time, the additions don't make it a "Gamer's Game", and add more luck with the tunnels, instead.

So, in my opinion TtR is the perfect gateway game, while you should buy TtR Europe only if you like its "brother" very much but after a lot of plays you want something slightly different.

I can see why this is a good gateway game though.

RATING: 7
A nice revision of TtR with a European map. The cards are all full-sized and therefore easier to hold in adult hands. The ferry and tunnel mechanisms are fun, while the stations allow you to recover from bad luck / sneaky play by your opponents. Personally I'd like to see the stations more expensive to build as they seemed a little too good last time. My only query is why the route between the UK and France that runs roughly from Folkestone to Calais is a ferry rather than a tunnel :-)

RATING: 5
Personally, I don't really feel like this game adds a lot to the original Ticket to Ride game, and I feel the emphasis on shorter tracks actually takes away from the some of the fun that was in the original.  The requirement of a locomotive on the ferries is a nice change, but nothing special. The tunnels really take away from the planning aspect of the game, and the train stations are certainly not a groundbreaking addition and take away from the "block your opponent" strategies which make the game more fun for advanced players.  All in all, I feel that this game takes away more fun from the original than it adds, but it maintains enough of the original gameplay to remain entertaining. Still, I'd always rather play the original game.

RATING: 4
I might like a tighter map better, to discourage card hoarding when playing with less than the full complement of players. But if I have 4 others to play with, we're not going to play ticket to ride so that is moot.

As I said, card hoarding is sufficiently uninteresting and removes any semblance of "network building" from the game, and instead overly rewards card counting and memorisation of the goal cards in the game.

Tunnels and the wildcard requirements for ferries I could do without as they add nothing of value - only a source of game created frustration when it should all stay "player made" so to speak.

Its very inoffensive, pretty too look at, easy to play and leaves room for talk etc. while playing - so ye... Meh... Play something else please?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Game in a Nutshell: Take the original and add stations to repair breaks in your chain and a few different types of track (tunnels and ferries) that have their own rules for completing those links.

Played as: 4,5 player (Online: 2,3,4,5 player)

Pros: Has all the same fun of the original. The biggest improvement after several plays of this and the original is how they fixed the complete randomness of the route cards, which allows players to stay competitive even with a spot of bad luck rather then being completely blown out of the water. Also the map seems balanced directionally as long routes can go just about any direction (and do, almost guaranteeing crossed paths)rather than being dominated by East-West or North-South.

Cons: The tunnels and ferries are kind of a draw as an addition. It's nice to force players to use wilds on the ferries, but can be bad when your best route requires them. The tunnels, especially through central/southern-Europe, can be intimidating and unforgiving on occasion. The stations can be anti-competitive, or a viable strategy, depending on how you look at it. And finally, the Europe map (compared to the US) itself isn't as intuitive to the US gaming core when used as a gateway.

Other: I really prefer this to the original USA version, and would pick this to play 9 times out of 10. I've raised my rating of this after I can't seem to stop playing the online version at the Days of Wonder website. 
Edit: I think I've finally hit my burnout level with this game after roughly 100 online plays (still I find myself coming back to it on occasion).

Best Use: A lighter 4-5 player gateway-game or played after a brain-burner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Este juego para mí fue toda una sorpresa. El juego llevaba un tiempo en la calle y yo había tenido la oportunidad de verlo un par de veces cuando jugaban unos amigos. Pero creo que cuando veía los componentes desplegados encima del tablero, no sé, me pasaba como con "A través del desierto", me echaba para atrás. Y eso que los componentes son de primerísima calidad y de un gusto exquisito, pero no sé, eso de ver vagones de colorines por todo el mapa me ponía nervioso. Hasta que un día no tuve más remedio que aceptar la invitación a jugar y descubrí la sencillez del juego y lo tremendamente adicitivo que puede llegar a ser construir una ruta. Además, es perfecto para repasar y ampliar los conocimientos de geografía. Por otra parte, la versión Europa no se distingue de la americana únicamente en el mapa del tablero. La Europea es una versión un pelín más avanzada donde se incluyen los túneles y las estaciones. A mi parecer, son reglas que aportan mayor variedad al juego, aunque muchos jugones lo critican. El lado malo del juego es la escasa interacción entre los jugadores: cada uno construye su vía a destajo. La única interacción es intentar chafarle la vía al prójimo antes de que te la chafe él a ti.

RATING: 9
Simple and elegant rules (always a plus for me), many interesting decisions during the game and very high tensions towards the end of the game. This is a fantastic mix of skill and luck and I prefer it to the original Ticket to Ride due to more familiar map and stations which prevent you from being completely blocked by somebody while giving you some additional strategic possibilities.
The rating difference between the top players and the average ones on Daysofwonder website is a very good proof that there is a lots of skill in this game. You've got to be very efficient, decisions in this game are deceptively light but often quite important for your overall score.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Incredibly well designed. Involved gameplay, easy to learn rules. If this were released a couple of decades earlier, it would be sitting right next to Monopoly on every store shelf: a classic released too late to capitalise on the glorious heyday of board gaming.

Only gripe is that the game never feels particularly "competitive" during the game. There is little to no interaction with other players gameplay-wise. A greater reliance on blocking other players out (perhaps by removing some of the routes allowing for two players to build upon) would make for substantially more exciting gameplay. That said, it's still great fun, and a must have. The "tunnel" rule in the Europe edition in particular is an interesting mechanic that allows for shortcuts or big points at the risk of losing turns and not gaining anything at all. Allows for some risky moves to be made on top of the otherwise straightforward gameplay.

Just wish they had the English names for the various European towns- fair enough, it was a choice in design, but the cities/towns are much easier to remember by location when you don't have to memorise their names first.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Easy to learn fast past game, surprisingly fun. Lacks player interaction.

RATING: 8
Great game. A lot of fun, with lots of different winning strategies to employ. 

Gripes:
- I hate the train stations. They undermine the ability to intentionally block your opponents' routes, which I can't stand. I mean, I hate it when its done to me, but that's part of the game! 

- Being an American, if I'm sitting on the North side of the board, it can be extremely difficult to find cities on the map, and this is only exacerbated by the fact that most of the cities are spelled with variations that most Americans would be unaccustomed to. Not a big deal, really, it just takes a little longer to find your ticket routes.

RATING: 9
The best thing about this game is how easy it is to teach. Everyone understands it really fast as there aren't a lot of rules.

However, those simple rules hide interesting and tense decisions as you're limited to only one action per turn.

Needs 3 or 4 players to make it really interesting though. With two players there is very little conflict as it's nearly impossible to be blocked by the other player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is by far my favorite version of the TTR series.  For more information on how the general game play works see my comments in the original version.  I will mostly be talking about differences here.

There are three differences in rules in the Europe version.  On top of those the cards are larger, I really don't like the small cards in the original version.  I know you can buy expansions now that give you a full set of cards that are larger, but it's not worth the money to me.  The first difference is that there are tunnels that are harder to build.  For example there may be a purple connection that needs two trains, but it's a tunnel.  So you announce you want to try and build a purple tunnel and first three cards are turned up from the top of the train cards.  For each of the cards that are turned up that are purple (since that is the color you're trying to build) you would need an extra card.  So for this 2 train connection if you were unlucky you would need 5 cards to build it on this turn.  You have the option to not build, either because you don't want to or don't have the cards, and you can try again on another turn, but you can't do anything else on your turn so you effectively lose your turn.  The second change is when going over bodies of water you need to build a ferry.  For each of these routes a certain number of locomotives are pictured, this tells how many wild cards you have to have in your set.  The last rule change are train stations.  When you get blocked on a connection, you can now build a train station at one end and use your opponent's connection as your own.

Probably the biggest difference that makes this  game the best for me is the lengths of the destination routes.  There are 6 long routes (worth around 20 points) and everybody gets one of those in their initial 3 routes.  You can still throw it out if you want, but usually you want to keep it.  From here on out there are no more long routes, I think the longest after that is only 13.  I think this just makes things more even and doesn't allow somebody to get those two long routes that are basically the same route so the scores will be more competitive.  If you are looking to buy one version of TTR, this is the one you want.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 2-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
MUCH better than the original U.S. Ticket to Ride.  The tunnels, the ferries, the stations...all are nice improvements.  But the biggest improvement is the board itself because it promotes competition.  I played a 5-player game and I had to deal with every other player in the game at some point as our paths were crossing and blocking and it was actually a lot of fun.  I had to use 2 of my stations to prevent catastrophic ticket point losses and won the game.  Was very satisfying.  If you have the original American map, burn it...BURN IT!!!  I prefer heavier games, but as a lighter family-type game this is very good.  I was surprised.  Played another 3-player game, won by nearly double the closest score to me, but the real problem was there was very little player interaction.  Not really a fan of the TTR series.

RATING: 10
A játékosok feladata a játék elején húzott célkártyák teljesítése, vagyis a játék végéig folyamatos vasútvonallal kell összekötni Európa térképén a kártyákon szereplő 2-2 várost. Az eredeti, USA-ban játszódó verzióhoz képest ez szerintem nehezebb, mivel annak viszonylag szimmetrikus a térképe, vagyis ha meg is építette előttünk egy másik játékos azt a szakaszt, amire nekünk is szükségünk volt, kis kerülővel mégis el lehetett érni a célállomást, azonban itt sokszor kerülünk olyan helyzetbe, hogy lehetetlenné válik egy-egy város megközelítése. Azonban az egyik újítás - a vasútállomás - orvosolja ezt a problémát. Újdonság még a játékban 2 újfajta szakasz típus: a komp és az alagút.
Ehhez a játékhoz viszonylag könnyű társat találni, mert általában mindenkinek bejön, elég egyszerű, a szabálymagyarázat is gyors, a játékidő sem hosszú. 
A sorozatból szerintem ennek van a legszebb táblája (és rajta van Budapest). Azért így a sokadik parti után már úgy tűnik, mintha a játékok ismétlődnének. 
(Az Europa 1912 kieg orvosolja ezt a problémát a rengeteg új útvonal kártyával.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Draft and play sets of cards to build train routes and connect tickets for most points.

Plays: More than 50.
Type: VP race = a game where you race to collect victory points (fastest/most).
Complexity: Family game = a game that is easy to teach and play.
# of players: 3-5.
Playing time: 10 mins per player.
Player interaction: Competition for routes.
Randomness: Medium - card draw. A bit lower than the USA version.

Replayability: Very high, often everyone wants to play again immediately.
Fun: The fun lies in the decision making of hand and board management.
Memorability: Low, it's a VP engine that doesn't create stories.

Thematic integration: Weak.
Components: Nice.
Expansions: Europe 1912 is not necessary.

Who will like this: Everyone. No kidding. This is a must-have in every game collection. I have yet to encounter anyone who doesn't enjoy TTR. Even non-gamers often buy their own copy after playing. If you get this or the USA version doesn't matter.

Old collection
