After a while, you know most long routes by heart though but then it makes it more interesting to block someone to keep him/her from finishing it... as a conclusion: a fast and enjoyable game that hits the table a lot when we don't want to play for hours or when we play with non-gaming friends.

We also bought the Europe 1912 expansion to include new long routes and of course some expansions and standalone versions like TTR Nordic Countries to make it interesting to play with two players only.

RATING: 8

Another good improvement i think is that the track lenght is a lot more evenly spaced out (i.e. you don't have A whole lot of Long tracks in the west and a whole lot of short tracks in the east). The tunnels also make the locomotive more attractive. If you have played Ticket to ride you will like this game. If you haven't play ticket to ride you should just skip ticket to ride and get ticket to ride:Europe

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
TtR:Europe is a slight improvement over the original TtR in that the variety of routes is increased with the inclusion of ferries, tunnels and stations.  Ferries and tunnels are pretty straight forward... they make the wild cards a bit more valuable than the base game and make the card draws a little more interesting imo. The stations I'm not as big a fan of. They pretty much cancel out blocking actions as you can now just place a station if you get blocked in an area (at a cost of 4 points though which is somewhat of a balancing effect). The fact that most routes in the game are now short routes and that everyone can only have at most 1 long route per game is more balanced as well as you really can't just load up on long routes by luck of the draw of the destination cards. Overall just slight changes in the game play from TtR but the game feels just a bit tighter and more balanced. It remains to be seen which version I prefer in the long run but the Europe version probably just VERY slightly edges out TtR 1910 USA and MÃ¤rklin at the moment. It's very close though as all three games are very similar and just give slight variances in the tactics/strategy of game play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.15
Base game

Light-medium
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I finally got to play this "gateway game" and Ticket to Ride certainly deserves its reputation. Simple and approachable with subtle interaction and a good balance between skill and luck. Plan your rail network based on hidden objectives but act before someone else claims a railway. Gamble to accept new objectives but be prepared to be penalized if you fail. A bit similar to the deeper Power Grid (which is recommended as the next game if you like Ticket to Ride).

In a comparison between Ticket to Ride and Ticket to Ride: Europe, the latter wins thanks to the more tactical opportunities offered by the stations and the tunnels.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played 1/5/2007 (3 players, 69 minutes);  9/7/2007 (5 players, ~77 minutes).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I don't know what it is about Ticket to Ride that I just don't really like. When I first purchased the game, I played it quite a bit.  It is a very accessible game, but quickly it seemed like all the games I was playing were the same.  With only a few long routes (of which you are guaranteed one), there didn't seem to be much play variety.  There also seemed to be a high correlation between the player who completed the one 6 (or is it 8?) length segment and the player who won.

Ticket to Ride is a good gateway game, it does play quickly, and it is easy to learn.  But I almost always prefer Settlers as a gateway game, and with my friends, I don't want to play Ticket to Ride. It's too short for a full game and too long for a filler, and really too light to be anything but a filler.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice little game that takes the mean vicious economic game of union Pacific and replaces it with route control. I miss UP!!! Warm fuzzy, and competative enough to be a decent game.  Light play, medium length.  Can see why it's predecessor  won the SdJ.

Play consists of quick turns that consist of taking new routes by playing sets of cards, completeing tickets (extended combinations of routes that give bonus points, primary scoring method), taking cards (since finishing routes is all about completeing sets of cards)  

Prefer TTR:E due to rules refinements (tunnels, wild cards, stations allowing to skeeze others routes) and bigger, better cards.  No reason to have both unless you are a die hard collector.  Reccomended for all levels and interests of  gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Don't know where this got to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Definitely the best of the series.

We have adjusted the point system and found it much more enjoyable and a little more balanced.  The problem is that we found the best strategy was simply to get your two or three tickets, then quickly extend your route with 4's and 6's to get out quickly and get the longest route.  No one would take tickets that went through Switzerland or any areas with lots of small routes, because they weren't worth the turns they took and the points that came with them.  Think about it: it takes two turns and fours cards to play two little "2's," but it takes one turn and four cards to play one "4" route.  If you pick up cards on that second turn, that means you have an advantage of two cards and three points because you could do a longer route than the other person who is doing the two short routes.  If those small routes happened to be tunnels, you may be down further numbers of cards, and you may have spent more turns getting cards just to make sure you had enough.  So . . . we simply make every train placed worth two points and the longest route worth 5 points.  We don't keep track of points until the end, when we go "look, I have three trains left, so I have 84 points ((45-3)x2).  The game is now almost always won by the person able to complete the most routes, though the longest route sometimes decides it,too.  No more counting and recounting points, and the game moves much more quickly, having really lost nothing of what makes us enjoy it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
We've played this the past two nights.  3 thumbs up!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The flip-a-card-and-see-what-happens aspect added to the basic TtR game just makes for an even more luck-based game, which pushes this further out into the realm of "who gives a flying..."
Now, not only do you need to draw the right cards in the first place, and draw the right route cards, but you need to draw the right cards in order to place trains on certain routes or lose your turn! Foolishness.
In the last game I played, one player was shut down four times on one tunnel while another blithely placed on tunnel after tunnel with no problem. Foolishness.
...also, the fact that the risk to place on a large and valuable tunnel is no greater than the risk to place on a stumpy little tunnel seems a bit off - but it is of no matter as I am unlikely to play this version of TtR again unless under extreme duress.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Plays best at 4 for me.

RATING: 7.6
I like the small changes here, and I think they do a lot to even out the game.  Setting aside the long routes is a good hedge against drawing a game killer when going for new destinations.  The stations give players an additional option when they find themselves blocked from completing a route.  The tunnels add a bit of unpredictability.  In all, a nice tweak to an already great game.

RATING: 8
IMHO the best of the "Tickets", especially with the 1912 expansion. We love the "no-hosed" factor that the stations provide, but never play with the "warehouses". 
The stations use means that you can't easily be accidently (or purposely) denied a town that is critical to your planning/tickets. To me that allows more options as to planning, and also less "luck of the draw" to playing. If you're hosed early it really makes the game pointless for the "hosed", hence probably not much fun from then on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
TTR for wimps. The stations make it too easy and destroy most of the tension of the main game.

The other changes are OK, not great, but no significative improvement:
-> Tunnels add a luck factor that was not necessary, but it's not especially annoying (makes up a bit for the stations luck of tension, but in a bad way; tension is generated by random elements, not by player decisions).
-> Locomotives are OK, a neutral change.

So, in general, changes are for worse, and the stations are a big mistake.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

I think it may be because the game is fast and and simple, you don't really have time to 'suspend disbelief' and imagine you really are a railway mogul.

RATING: 7.8
Exactly a family game. Easy to teach. Fun to play. You can play it with not-experienced board gamers too. Be sure they will like it. As you know some people does not like board games. They can see how funny playing board games can be by starting playing with Ticket To Ride. You cannot teach detailed games to these people but this one is easy to teach. No in game language texts, good usage of colors, quality game pieces and board. Balanced game and great game idea is included behind. Every game is not won by same person but generally better one wins but not 100%. A bit luck is included and it effects winner about 30%. Of course you also have to use your brain. A totally stupid one cannot win any game. Can playable fast it can end in 40-45 minutes in average after you experience some. Great replability, you can replay up to 5 times in some days. All families should have one. 

Increased score 0.2 points after playing its IPAD version tons of time.

RATING: 8
If there's not enough time for a more involved game (e.g. Puerto Rico) or there some more casually oriented gamers at the table (e.g. my parents) then this game is one of the two staple games that comes to the table. While there is a lot of luck in the game, there are always choices to be made, and there are usually some big swings both mid-game and in end-game scoring that makes everyone feel involved the whole way. Add to that the excellent production values and this game is a real winner for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a good game - just not as good as TTR.  There isn't really anything that this game does better than the original.

The tickets overlap less so it feels there are fewer opportunities to change up your plan on the fly.  It's a little more scripted.

It's pretty obvious which long destination ticket people have.

Stations are a pain unless you really have to use them.  Tunnels and ferries - ditto.  I'm sure that's the idea, but this game is just less fun and usually ends farther apart in scores.

I like to play it - but only when I need a break from other TTRs ;)

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
"At least with 4-5 players and some first-timers, this game just takes TOO LONG, at 90-105 minutes. It would be an OK (not great) 45-minute game, but it far outstays any welcome. Beyond that, I don't particularly enjoy the gameplay. I do like the stations in this version, but am not fond of the tunnels."

What I like:
- Reasonably easy to teach
- I like the stations in this Europe edition

What I don't like:
- Takes way too long (90-105 minutes with 4-5p)
- Placing trains on the map doesn't interest me
- Blocking can be a bit nasty
- Confusion between track colors and player colors
- Not a huge fan of the tunnels, but they're not terrible

An adequate game, but vastly overrated. Way too long with 4-5p, at least if there are a few newer players (my 2 games have taken 90 and 105 minutes). Complicated enough (with the tunnels, bridges, and stations) that a couple newbies really struggled to understand it.

Definitely would not be my first choice as a gateway game. (Nor would Settlers of Catan, for what that's worth). After my second play, I'm reducing my rating from 5 to 4.

RATING: 7.7
I really wasn’t sure about this one. I bought it mostly because it is considered a must have, fearing I was in for a boring and “broken rules” experience. 

I still don’t think the game is sth exceptional on terms of gameplay, rules, interaction, etc.

It’s just addictive. I want to play the game over and over again. I am bewitched. I can’t explain why, so I can’t recommend it hands down, but it happened to me and I am really glad about it.

Maybe it has to do with the classy huge game board and the colorful cards and components. Every game is sth of a feast. A great event everyone want's to be a part of. Very little downtime.

I am having fun every time I’m playing it and when the game ends I want to play it again. That’s more than enough for me!

(Wife's Point of View: One of the few board games in my collection that she trully enjoys and can be played with 2players. She hates strategy games but this one is light and interesting enough. I don't care why but thankfully it works)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After a long period in which I have had absolutely no time to give to gaming, it's now a period in my life in which I restarted and I want easy and funny games, with few rules and a deep playing.This is the perfect game. It's quick to learn and to explain, immediate to understand, satisfying, strategic and tactic, colourful and interactive.Very good. It's a direct consequence of Union Pacific, made better and easier, taking elements from TransAmerica and Catan (the longest road). About doubts, I have a doubt about the ticket's score, as soon as in the few games that I played appeared that it's far more convenient to build long lines and limit to just have 2 easy tickets. The only line of 8 is worth 21 points, more than a long ticket (although a ticket is actually worth double points, because it's negative if you fail) and of course the one that is able to make this line first is just the luckiest. But probably it won't be anymore when I learn to play better.Tunnels and ferries are something more, but actually not very important for the game, while staions are definitely a must for the strategy. I cannot understand how the original game could live without stations.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another great game.  It adds 3 new rules to Ticket to Ride US (tunnels, ferries, and railroad stations) which make the game very interesting.  There are only 6 long routes, though, so those are too predictable when someone starts building them (needs more long destination options).  Also, there are a few too many short connections between cities, so it's a little more claustrophobic than the wide open original US version, but I like the new rules, particularly the railroad stations because if someone blocks your route you can play a railroad station and use their track segment to complete your route anyway.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Despite the fact that some people feel the train stations nerf the game too much, I actually feel like they are necessary to deal with the many bottlenecks.  If too many people are west or east, it can be a brutal game anyway.

I love how difficult some of the routes are to complete, especially late in the game where some sections get really choked.  And unlike US, there seem to be more "sections" that your tickets might focus on.  Perhaps you will start off with Baltics/south-east, perhaps no one will touch Italy until the last few rounds, perhaps no one will go to Scandinavian areas, I like the variety.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
E 24.99 1.4.17
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Eh, it's ok. I don't dislike the game at all, but there are so many games I like more. This just feels a little vanilla. I feel like this version occupies a strange middle space in terms of complexity/depth. The new mechanisms make it just complex enough that it is difficult to introduce to people that don't play many games (I think the original is much easier to teach). On the other hand, it still doesn't give me quite enough to chew on. I'm fine with games that have relatively simple rule sets, if (1) they are quick and light or (2) a deep strategy can emerge from a relatively limited decision space.  This doesn't really provide either of those for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(1 play)  

Who can play?  Family game for 3-6 players.

Easily as good as the original Ticket to Ride.  The added options and rules are good, and make the game more strategic and interesting, but also longer.  For my collection, I'll stick to the original, since the European cities are harder to locate for the wide variety of people I'm likely to play with.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Makes an excellent rotation with the base game.

Pros:
* Stations add a much needed element to assist those who get blocked.
* Maps of Europe are always fun to play on.

Cons:
* City names can be confusing to their current form.
* People will whine about the tunnels instead of properly preparing for them.
* A tighter map than the U.S. and it is much easier to get blocked in a 5-player game.

RATING: 8
The game feels a bit more structured than any of the others. Having the 'long route' sets the tone for where you're going to generally be going, which adds a layer of simplification for new players. The train stations are a welcome addition, and bring a new layer of detail without adding too much additional complexity. Full sized train cards are an obvious plus. While this may change after getting the 1910 expansion, I prefer TTR: Europe to the original.

RATING: 7
MUCH better than the old one.  Everything I disliked has been fixed: 1) uneven route distributions, 2) when your ticket is cut off you can still make the connection - for a smaller penalty, and 3) there is a much bigger advantage to getting the locomotives.  I never find myself suggesting to play it, but I always enjoy it.

RATING: 9
It is an easy to learn game. Every new player can get involved in a short time. Need to have a planning at the beginning for complete the long distance destination card if you want to win. The map is great and in high quality. My friends like the plastic small trains.
A suggestion, put the map at the end of your table and arrange all players to sit surround the map in a U-shape because it will be very difficult for a player to look at the map with upside-down view if sit at the top side of it.

RATING: 9
My favourite gateway game and my favourite implementation of the Ticket to Ride series (I haven't played Marklin yet). For 2 or 3 players though I'd really suggest picking up the Switzerland map. Either way, I like the bit of randomness that the tunnels bring. Also, Europe isn't as ticket driven as some of the other TtR games and it is harder to screw people over because of the stations. Switzerland is all about the tickets though and certainly rewards blocking if your group chooses to play that way. (Mine usually doesn't. Usually.)

It scales up nicely from 2-5 players as well and no one feels lost.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the modern family game! The fairly straightforward gameplay and rules are very accessible even for beginners. Basically the same game as the original but set in pre-WWI Europe and with a few additions.

The biggest difference is the addition of stations. These  let the owner use another players connection that would otherwise be blocked off. This takes away a lot of of the original games conflict since it makes it a lot harder to block off another player.

The tunnels make some connections harder and less predictable as they may require up to three additional cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Had to play this to see if the changes added anything better over the original. I love the bigger cards, but the board seems busier than the US map. My other first impression is that the stations don't seem to be that necessary and complicate proceedings a little. But the strange thing for me is the building through tunnels as this involves alot of card monitoring, and if you get your timing wrong, you miss a turn, which feels disastrous. Otherwise its the usual target induced tension and angst filled dilemma of picking up much needed cards or taking a route before someone else does. Nice feelings to have, but evaporate once you go through the evaluating and scoring and by then I don't care anymore. A bit like eating dessert and then having to wash up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
-

The TtR 1910 and Marklin edition are superior games vs Europe. The new elements in this game add more randomness, chaos, and unpredictability.

A lot of luck and randomness have been introduced: To build some route segments you must use one or two wild cards and the tunnels may require additional wild cards. The importance of wild cards has been dramatically raised, unnecessarily increasing the luck factor.

Many of the route segments on this map are single routes and the map overall is very unforgiving. Although this produces more tension in the game, the tension isoften of the unpleasant kind. You constantly have to worry weather you will be able to complete your routes in this tight map. The stations help of course, but that's partial consolation.

In spite of all this, the game is better than the original TtR, which has a flaw with its too few destination cards.

Beware that in TtR:E it is much more risky than the original game (and Marklin) to draw destination tickets rather late in the game.

-

RATING: 6
Dragged for me the time that I played it. I put a lot of effort into making sure I could finish my routes, finished them and had nothing else to do. The game went on longer than I expected. Turns out I should have taken more routes. But how was I to know this? Supposedly a gateway game but seemed punishing to newbies who weren't familiar with the optimal number of routes to take. Too much chaos. Only one play, so would play again but not excited about this one.

Edit: Upgraded rating to 7. There is enough strategy in the drawing cards vs claiming routes to keep me interested, and it fills the gateway niche well as apparently some players can get well over 100 points on their first play.

Edit: Back down to 6. I don't like the stations--they tilt the game toward drawing train cards and playing all your trains at the end since you can always throw down a station if someone claims some of your track.

In some respects I enjoy TTR Europe more - in particular the need for wilds in the ferries as the tunnel building rules. I also like the long vs short route differentiation. The stations make the blocking moves a bit less devastating.
I can see why this is a popular game

G - Toralf
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I usually get suspicious when someone takes an already great game and starts adding new rules. There is always the fear that they will break the game system in some fundamental way. Therefore I was pleasantly surprised to find that the additions in TTR:Europe are only minor alterations, and not a huge make over. Here are some examples:
- All players are dealt a long route (20 points or more) at the start of the game which helps establish a more level playing field
- There are now tunnel and ferry routes that require some extra strategy
- There is a new station piece that helps prevent players from being blocked out of an important destination. I have not seen anyone take advantage of this yet, but the idea is neat.
Overall its a great game that maintains the fun of the original while adding some new twists. Ticket To Ride is one of the best games on the market, and the European variant is even better. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Birthday Present
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife introduced Ticket to Ride: Eurpoe to my sister-in-law, Heidi.  After that single two player game Heidi's response was, "We need to get this game!"  There's something absolutely addictive about Ticket to Ride: Europe.

The game is easy.  Players draft sets of cards in order to connect cities on the board for which they get points.  Players also have ticket cards that require them to connect two cities on the board for points and penalties if they fail to do so.  And of course, each connection shown on the board can only be used once, in a first come first serve fashion, which adds an element of blocking and can sabotage other players' tickets.

At it's heart T2R:E is a race game.  The opening game takes the form of a Mexican stand off.  Players collect the cards they need to complete their tickets while suspiciously noting each other's draws.  But once connections start getting played it will invariably threaten some one else's desired route.  So there is constant competition and constant tension as players race to complete the best routes and their tickets before the game ends.  This tension only increases for the half hour to 45 minutes it takes to play a game.

I've only played the origianl Ticket to Ride a couple of times.  It felt much less intense since there seemed to be more connections and fewer harsh bottle necks.  In T2R:E there exist Train Stations that enable palyers to use their opponents' connections to complete tickets.  Without these, tickets would be suicide and break that whole aspect of the game.  As it is players are much less likely to take tickets in T2R:E than normal T2R.

T2R as a game system suffers from a serious flaw.  It's hard to expand.  Days of Wonder can't just print up a new map and a sheet of rules as seen in Power Grid and Age of Steam expansions.  Each new map needs a set of corresponding Ticket cards.  And if you are already printing a board and cards and a box to conatin them all, you're most of the way to a new game.  I suspect this is why T2R variants tend to be self contained games.  Which is too bad, for me anyway, since that's the main reason I haven't bought any other versions of Ticket to Ride.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
i don't care for this version. i'm perplexed how the additional elements in this version of ticket to ride, the tunnels and stations, make this more of a "gamer's game," as everyone has been saying. does a game automatically become more interesting through the addition of a few more rules? i think this game proves otherwise. as it stands the tunnels feel too arbitrary and the stations subtract from the tension of building routes vs taking cards. the last point can't be overstated.  without the tension between building routes or taking cards, what really is there to the system?  i can't ever see myself ever wanting to play this version over the original or marklin.

RATING: 10
Disclaimer: rated as a gateway game!

Okay, so "Ticket to Ride" is not really MY kind of game. Too easy, a bit too random and so on. So why the 10? Because it's the ultimate gateway. Honestly, we tried this with many, many people, newcomers to the hobby mostly, and they ALL loved it. Wanted to play again. And again, and again. Friends, family, cats and dogs... They just can't get enough of it!

But more to the point - "Europe" seems to be the best of the crop. Has a bit more strategic options (ferries, tunnels, train stations), the map's great - but play it with 4 or 5! - there are also some great lil' expansions with new tickets... If you look for an accessible, fun and smart game for newbies - or even for experienced gamers who sometimes like to relax over the game board - get it. It's a no brainer.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I just bought this for a friend and recently played my first game.  I can certainly see why people recommend this as a good gateway game.  The rules are straight-forward, but there are plenty of decisions to make and lots of room for strategy.  From guessing the other players' intentions and blocking them, to secretly completing your own missions, to the eternal question of whether to complete a route or take more train cards, there is never an idle moment.  Player moves quickly, players are always involved, and you are always progressing towards your goal.

We didn't play with the Europe additions, so I can't really comment on them.  It seems like it might add one more dimension to the strategy, but I don't see it being a game changer.  We were just as happy to not use it our first time.

The only problem we had with it was figuring out what tickets to keep.  It was hard to find the relevant places on the map.  Considering we are Canadian and none of us are particularly knowledgeable about European geography, it may have been more difficult for us than it would be for Europeans.  The cards themselves did try to alleviate this by showing roughly where they are on the whole map, but it still needs something more.  Hopefully after a few plays we will begin to memorize the locations of the cities.

It's a simple game that moves quickly, keeping players involved, and leaves lots of room for strategy.  So far, it's an excellent game that I will happily play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I enjoy this game more than Ticket to Ride.  I am very eager to play again, but I'm unsure of depth.  This may go down a bit after the shine is off.

The Stations mean that one mistake (or one vandal) does not absolutely destroy you.  If your group likes to cut each other off and screw the other guy, you may wish to limit the number of stations, increase their cost or make the victory point penalty for using them higher.  I'll play a few more times before making a decision but I think I will reduce the number of stations in the 2 and 3 player games.  We added 8 more trains each when playing 2 player.  That worked fairly well.

We have played where ferries and tunnels are treated as regular routes.  No great difference to the game. The larger number of grey routes is a nice feature.  It makes it more likely that people will clash over them. 

I love the larger cards and I'm charmed that the city names are in their own language.

The game has enough luck that occasionally people just playing for fun will win.  This will drive some hard core gamers mad, but it makes it easier to expand the hobby to new people. 

EDIT: I've played this game dozens of time now and have used it as a gateway game to introduce new people to board games many times.  I've not bothered with any of the changes I was thinking about above - we have been enjoying the game as written.  Still a '9'.

Played many more times.  Still using basic rules with no tweaks.  Dropped rating to an 8.5.

RATING: 6.5
An excellent gateway game, albeit a little light playing on the Europe map due to easier routes and inclusion of stations.

I have introduced my fiancée, my mother and her boyfriend to board-gaming via TTR Europe. My fiancée spoke highly of the game to her family, and we introduced her bother and her brother's wife to the game. This is my gateway game of choice when introducing the hobby to non-gamers.

Downgraded to a 6.5 after a couple of plays. A little light for me - although the above comments stand re: excellent gateway - and the Europe map w/stations lacks tension. I will buy the Africa map after a few more plays on the Europe map, to add some much needed interaction and meanness to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played this until 4 am during Christmas time. It is a wonderful game. It takes the original game and adds a few twists to it - train depots help you from being blocked out, Tunnels to add an educated gambling, and ferries to make some routes tougher to build. 

One thing to note - the map is of Europe, but circa 1912. So many cities are not familiar. Also the city names are not familiar English names. For example, Athens, Greece is called Athena. This is not an impediment to the game for me, but it certainly different from the USA version. 

Considering the above, the minimum age is a few years higher than the USA version. I don't think my 9 year old could handle the Europe version yet. Perhaps when he is 12.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not bad.  The elegant simplicity of the original is lost a little, but on the plus side, the risk management questions are more interesting.  In the original, the tickets are the only source of risk taking.  Here, you can consider how gutsy you want to be in laying down tunnel track and placing stations.  Finally, emphasis on short routes and on short tracks is a definite plus, leading to more interesting tactical problems.  Given the choice between playing the original and playing this, I would probably choose this.  Still, because the original is more accessible, that's the one more likely to be pulled out when I have non-gamers at the table.  And when I have gamers, Marklin is a tastier choice.  So this game stands in the unfortunate role of 'palate cleanser'--something to play every now and then just because it's a little different from the others.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My personal average rating across TtR, TtR:Europe, TtR:Nordic Countries, and TtR: Germany.

I feel that TtR:Europe is elevated further by its expansion, with the warehouses providing a means of immediate surplus cards and the opportunity to leech off of your opponent's tracks.

See my comments on the original game for my thoughts.

RATING: 7
I like this game a lot, and it gets a lot of play time with my particular group of friends, thanks to its simplicity and agreeable theme.  I think I would rate this a bit higher if it had a bit more interaction between players.  Yes, you can claim routes to block and annoy your opponents, but in my experience this doesn't seem to happen as frequently as it does on the USA board - this is alleviated even more by the existence of stations to share other players' routes.  Some might enjoy this reduced level of player adversity, but I like a bit more competition - take this from a player who currently owns ZERO cooperative board games!

RATING: 8.2
Great set collecting and route building game. As with Ticket to Ride, I like that each leg of a route scores points and that there isn't a central hub that you have to grow your route out of. The additions of stations make for a more forgiving game, and the separation of long and short routes goes a long ways towards balancing out some of the issues with Ticket to Ride. I also like the addition of ferries and tunnels. In just about every way this is a superior game to the original.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
22-02-2015. Rated after like 5 plays or such. I am famous in my local gaming group for disliking Ticket to Ride, but I'll quickly cover it regardless.

In ticket to ride, you either get cards from the central offer, or closed cards from the top of the deck. You then try to build routes that you'll score VPs for. You build a track by discarding as many train cards of a certain color as the length of the track. You score more points for longer routes you finish, but most points are won (and lost) for connecting the routes you got on route cards. These consists of multiple tracks. 

The game is ok, I see that the mechanisms are solid. To me, it's just too light, too abstract/dry to keep me interested. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Luck based, really dry game.

RATING: 6.5
Great game - I like Europe better than USA for 5 players although both are much better with 4 players.  The stations add an interesting aspect where you can try to predict which long route your opponents might do for you and you can ride them, although that may not be a winning strategy. The tunnels add a nice "press your luck" aspect.  After more plays with the other expansions, Europe is slowly going down in my rating - just don't enjoy it as much for some reason.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My favorite of the TTR series so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Tickret to ride is a very popular game wbere players collect colored train cards in order to claim routes on the board. Every completed route card scores you victory points. This european version is much friendlier than the regular game and it is harder to have your routes cut off by other players.  This game is fun, but there are no really deep decisions to be made.

Pros:quick playing time,beautiful artwork and components. 

Cons:no deep thinking of strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not as good as the original in my book. Why add stuff thats not needed? It was fine, but I would never own both versions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]Traded away 20 April 2012[/b]

Slightly different than TTR with the USA map. I own both USA & Europe and don't know that they're different enough to warrant owning both, in hindsight. 

I don't enjoy this game with 2-3 players and would rate it a "4". With 4-5 players, the game is much, much more fun, and I would rate it near a "7". Likely it won't be my first choice, but if someone else suggests it I'll play and will have a good time.

My main problem with this game is the lack of theme, which may be more important to me than many others. If theme doesn't matter to you, you're likely to enjoy this game.

The two redeeming qualities it has are: (1) It's a good gateway game. (2) Far more enjoyable with more than 2-3 players.

RATING: 9.2
Ticket to Ride is really more of an abstract game rather than a true railway game - if you can accept this, the series is excellent. TTR Europe is easily the most interesting and replayable of this series. Stations are also very useful added back to other expansions, especially India and Germany. We don't usually play with Depots as they don't add any interest to the game and just slow it down.

RATING: 7.5
[color=#CC0000]

    I personally like this game better than the original for two reasons -- the map is a bit more fun and the introduction of stations prevents a player from spending their entire time blocking you.  In my opinion the original is little fun with two players.  This game is -- blocking just doesn't pay.  With three or more the original gets more intense than this one -- decide which you prefer before buying.

    Bigger cards than the original and they're beautiful, along with the board.  A pretty game -- and a definite first choice for introducing newbies into the game world.

    As with the original, the online play is excellent (comes included with the board game) as the machine manages all the bookwork.  But the board is worth having too.

[/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Nice set collecting game. A bit on the lucky side, but still with an element of skill. I like: ferries, tunnels, route distribution; don't like: stations, drawing cards endlessly.

The fabled DoW production quality turns out to be pretty unremarkable, about on par with Abacus or Kosmos, but with plastic trains instead of the wooden pieces a German company would have given us. Bring on an all wood edition!

Good with 2 or 5, though I prefer Andromeda for 3-4 players. I'm going to hold off on buying this, because I think a better version with less card drawing is still to come. It needs one more iteration to get there, basically.

Probably more of a 6 than a 7 for me, but it gets another point because I thought about it after playing it and want to play again and try some different things next time. Always a good sign.

Update: played some more TtR and was less impressed... dropped it to 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A few points about the accessibility of this game:
- No reliance on in game text.
- Visual mechanics.

These make the game very easy to teach/learn, and can be played with all the family no matter what their native tongue is (especially useful in mixed language families) - you only need one person to be able to read the rules and you are good to go.

Visual mechanics of seeing the board, the trains on it, the score board, the cards to draw (other than the blind deck) - make it intuitive to remember what you are supposed to do - good when learning, or for non-gamers/children etc.

The physical nature of the trains also appeal to me as a gamer and I find there is enough to think about/conflict in the game to keep me interested as a light euro game to play with a nice half pint of homebrew.

Marked as previously owned as I bought this for my sister (so it's technically true that I briefly owned it).

RATING: 5
I view it as a lowest common denominator: anybody can be taught how to play: your children, your declared game opposing friends, your grandparents. Can be fun, especially if you use expansions tailored for specific group size and to spice things up. Superior to the base (US) version, as the stations offer a way out of beeing blocked out of a route, giving you more control at the expense of being a bit friendlier and less cutthroat at the same time. Not much interest for gamers here, though, Stone Age, Settlers of Catan are both heavier and more complex.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The missus and my first game at the Liverpool Lions boardgaming club and a very enjoyable welcome to the hobby. Mrs F plays this obsessively online, I like it, but generally prefer to play something else. Prefer the variety of strategies to the original, but it definitely misses out on some of the elegant simplicity. Also, the stations make the game a lot harsher on beginners, and favour knowing the ticket deck.
Edit (Oct 2010): My opinion has mellowed, and I find I generally enjoy TTR:E, 2 players or more. My previous thought that stations are "harsh" on beginners may have been influenced by the game I played being a very cut-throat 6-player bash. Now I have played Big Cities from 1912 I really want to get the expansion

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I find that when I'm not playing the game, I'm thinking up new strategies to try next time. I like how there are different approaches one can take: focus on the long route destination, build many small route destinations, build just the high scoring routes, or try to block others. It allows players to focus on their own goals but also provides opportunities for player interaction.

I love the production quality and the big board. It's a quality product. I don't play it all the time because it requires more than an hour to play but it is very satisfying even when I don't win, especially with the final scoring and the revealing of destination cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Bought this instead of original Ticket to Ride because it says it has a more advance gameplay. So yes, look at the rating I gave. Why I love it? Well, it's fun laying out those trains and finding your path to your destinations. Strategy is high enough to make me plan my movement up ahead. Picking up some right destination tickets is surely the core to win this. It's less forgiving because of the train station you can build. It's easy to learn. Some quarrelling over railways will oftenly occurs, but trust me...it's the most peaceful and quiet person on the table that usually wins the game. 

I love how the long destination routes is different from each other so people won't oftenly got clashed together fighting for the railways. Insist players to keep their long destination ticket, unless you want to play a game from hell keep just the short routes. 

This has been a house favorite. It has been played more than 5 times in a week right after I bought it.

This game is rated for family, but I will recommend this to be played with kids above 10 because there will be a tense fight after someone blocked your way. My cousin who rarely curse can just shout "damn it" after her sister blocked all her path and it's hilarious. So, buy this. This too has a legendary status on my collection. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Spel dat iedereen leuk zal vinden, perfect instapspel dus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
On par with Ticket to Ride, with the following changes: 1) A different map. (Europe, you may have heard of it.) 2) "Ferry" routes REQUIRE one or more wildcards in the mix. 3) "Tunnel" routes may require an additional train card to complete. 4) Train stations may be placed on cities allowing the station owner to choose one connecting route and act as if it is their own for destination ticket purposes. MAP. The map uses city names other than what we Americans call those cities, so it takes a little getting used to. It has no 5-car length routes, strangely enough, but it does have a 8-car tunnel. FERRIES. Ferries are kind of pointless. The small ferry routes are good, but for the large routes what's the big deal about spending a wildcard you probably would have spent anyway? TUNNELS. Tunnels add an element of arbitrary punishment I don't like. You draw three cards from the pile. For each card drawn that matches the color of the train cards you played, this tunnel requires you play an additional matching card or wildcard. If you can't afford these extra train cards, you have to take back your cards/trains and lose your turn. Adds a small cost increase and gambling element to the game, but nothing major or all that appealing. And as for the train stations -- this is the only part of the game I consider an improvement. Each city can hold one station only, and each player has three stations. Unplayed stations are worth four points. Stations add more choices, allowing new strategies for piggy-backing on an opponent's route. My suggestion? If you have the original Ticket to Ride, use that and make your own train stations. TTR:Europe is a good game, and kicks a little life into one of the more overplayed games in my collection. I prefer the purity of the original.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Just didn't work for the group
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Marginally better than the basegame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The stronger use of locomotives and addition of tunnels makes this a better game in my mind than Ticket to Ride (by just a little bit).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For gamers, this is a much more interesting variation that requires a little more planning and less dumb luck.  The Long Tickets are still the fatal flaw though, and possibly worse in this game as you rapidly learn what they are.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Can't go past the TtR series! This is an excellent game to have in the collection, as it usually goes down very well with new players, and also holds up well to repeated plays. The TtR games play so well in my opinion because they maintain the players' interest throughout the game by allowing for a great mix of short, medium- and long-term planning and achievement of goals.

Some comments on specifics of the game, particularly the elements distinguishing the Europe version from the original:

The routes seem more well-balanced than the USA map, and the ticket selection process is also much fairer (everyone having the chance to take one, and only one, long route).

At an initial glance stations may seem like a cheap way out, but in practice they are well-balanced in terms of cost (points+cards), and help make drawing of tickets late in the game a more tempting option - a definite plus in my opinion.

I didn't think much of tunnels when I first read how they worked, but they aren't as bad as I thought - a bad card draw can be harsh, but it does add a bit of extra drama to the game. When someone's trying to claim a tunnel, it tends to grab everyone's attention while the cards are flipped over.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As a newcomer to the hobby, surrounded primarily by non-gamers, I've begun to grow a collection with the aim of progressing toward the somewhat heavier games that seem to appeal to me. I'm still developing my own tastes, but things like Power Grid, Goa, Tikal, BaM, etc., peak my interest. I'm hoping to chart a course that starts off with lighter weight games.

For me, Ticket to Ride: Europe has already worked remarkably well. I opened it on Christmas Eve and played a game with my brother and his wife - neither of whom particularly enjoy games. It went down very well. Three days later, with two additional players, we played Bohnanza followed by TtR:E. The new players asked where they could get both games. The next day, with 4 different players, I introduced TtR:E again, with the same result - everyone enjoyed it, and each couple asked where they could get a copy. The day after that my brother (who didn't care for games) asked to borrow TtR:E to play with some guests. He's also asked where he can get his own copy. I'd call that a good start.

Ticket to Ride: Europe is a good game. I don't mind playing, and I have no problem suggesting it (in fact, I wish it supported more players). And - while I don't find it particularly stimulating - I was surprised by the amount of tension it produced in the other players. For some reason, they all seemed to get deeply invested into the game. I wish I could say the same, but it still felt good seeing how much they liked it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Only one play, but I fail to see how this improved upon the original. And I don't see how someone who didn't like the original is going to somehow appreciate this version more. The "station" marker which prevents one from getting locked out of a segment removes one of the key components of the original for me; The tension of whether I might get squeezed out and should I act now and risk telegraphing my plans?  The added conditions of having to play additional cards for tunnels I feel also defeats the elegance of the original. Finally, the new map may address some of the perceived issues with the original map, but I've not yet played it enough to form a solid opinion on that, but after my initial play, I didn't see an obvious improvement. But then I don't see any issues with the original map either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This used to be the gateway game of choice I pulled to entice non-gamers, because the rules are so short. But it hasn't worked out: potential gamers find it too simple, while non-gamers aren't enticed by the theme (plastic trains aren't cool for a lot of people). There is also such a thing as simple gameplay obscuring the appearance and value of strategy.

With all TTR games, I get into it and like the game once we start playing, but I will rarely request to play it. Europe is more troublesome than the other TTR to teach, due to the one-locomotive rule when taking from the table, ferries, tunnels and stations, and this matters because every little new rule adds up when you're teaching to non-gamers. Tunnels are stupid. Not sure I like the stations (screwed means SCREWED!). Weakness of this (and all TTR games) is that the game is a tad too quiet to let non-gamers have a good time.

Oh, and I got the Europe version, because I thought it'd be cool to brush up on my European geography. Guess what? Americans don't give a rat's ass about learning geography. Better stick to the original TTR if you're teaching non-gaming Americans! They're already unfamiliar enough with the premise of strategic board games; the map can be a calming reference point for them.

Switzerland: 3+2
Nordic: 3+2
Marklin: 3+2
Europe: 2+2

Only after the game I realised there's not a lot of game in there, but hey, for certain groups probably the best choice. 

I personally prefer European map over American, firstly we are from Europe, secondly I like stations and ferries. It moves the game from being cut throat to calculating risks (from tactical to a bit more strategic). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game scales well. When playing with new people you can take out the stations and build tunnels using normal rules.  Then introduce these back into the game once everyone is familiar with the care game.  The game also feels much more balanced than the original TTR.  Every player gets a long route so everyone has the potential to make about the same number of points from their tickets.  My main complaint is the abundant grouping of tunnels in one area of the board can add difficulty but the point values of routes through those areas do not reflect that difficulty.  Also I personally prefer the US map better, but that may be because I live in the US and played that version first.  I can't point to anything in particular on the US map that is better than the Europe map.

RATING: 10
Love it, love it ,love it! So simple but so much fun!! Tom and I are always rating our games in different categories and this is my number 1 for fun!! Get it...play it ...and have some fun!

We play with a few house rules as well:

...Score your destinations as you complete them (can see who is winning as the game unfolds)

...Keep your destinations dealt to you at the start of the game in 2, 3 and 4 player games (adds more tension in trying to complete your routes)

...In 2 player games deal 4 short routes and 1 long route to each player with 5 train cards at the start ,keeping all. (even more tension to complete)

...Take off the 4 points for a station as you use it.

...Maximum hand size is 15 cards

...All pass a short destination to the player on your left to keep if at least 1 person agrees.

We have played TtR many , many times implementing these changes and believe they just make a great game even better!!

Update: 2p game-fill destination tickets for a dummy player to at least 40 trains.Have these take the shortest routes possible.This simply makes the board more crowded for your game.Super!

2p:20 mins. 3p:30 mins. 3+p:40+ mins.
>100

RATING: 6.5
More Ticket to Ride goodness. I find the map messier and less elegant. The new elements (stations, tunnels and ferries) just add more 'chrome' and reduce the overall simplicity of the original.

I like the larger train cards (a very nice touch) and the fact that you get 1 long route card and 2 short ones. 

There are only 2 really long lines and more than 80% of the lines are short (2-4 train lengths).

Nothing really new to justify buying a copy.

RATING: 8
Лучшая из коротких игр!!! Очень хороша на двоих, особенно Америка! Европа лучше на  троих, зато даже на четверых в игре нет хаоса - поля хватает для напряженной игры всех игроков.
В сравнении с Северной Америкой, карта играется совершенно по другому. К ней надо привыкнуть. Она труднее к освоению. Хороши новшества: большие маршруты, станции (их особенно не хватает стартовой игре). Тунели и паромы тоже игру не портят. Но ощущение от игры, как это не странно, несколько другое, если сравнивать её с Северной Америкой - у Америки более простая карта, в Европе менее очевидные маршруты - из них меньше тех, которые "вкладываются" один в другой, а значит и набор Тикетов, более опасен и сложен нежели в первой игре серии.

Still easy to learn and teach. Same rating for me as original...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A nice update of TtR, which was one of our favorite games of the year.  Decisions are more difficult and our games seem to be much closer and more hotly contested.  Most of the time, the winner of the "Longest Train" route is a deciding factor in the victory.  Use of tunnels and ferrys are a welcome addition, although the tunnel rules don't seem quite right (try tunnel, and get told it requires 3 cards instead of four, then just try tunnel again next turn and get the same tunnel for 3 again....)  Train stations are a nice "cost/benefit" mechanism encouraging the taking of additional tickets.  It would have been nice to see more than just 6-7 "long train" routes, as the "I know what route you have" factor comes into play pretty easily.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This version of Ticket to Ride solves a lot of the balance issues I experienced with the core game. Long route cards are distributed evenly among players, there are fewer long segments of track (no segments of length five, two of length six, and one of length eight), and train stations mitigate the effect of blocking routes. I enjoyed the additional tunnel, train station, and locomotive-specific track mechanics.

Blocking routes was very easy in certain cases in the core game; when a player decides to do so, it can be difficult or impossible to complete routes. Route blocking still impacts players by forcing the use of a train station. However, this leads to four less points for that player, rather than potential 40+ point swings. Route-blocking really saps enjoyment out of the game for some people I regularly play with, though I understand other groups may enjoy the conflict.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun game. Like it better than TTR USA.

RATING: 8
[2011-03-27]
Az alapjáték Európában, vasútállomásokkal, alagutakkal és kompokkal megbolondítva. Nagyon szép kivitelezésben.

Az állomások érdekesebbé teszik a játékot. Nagyobb eséllyel vállal be valaki útvonalhúzást így, mint az alapjátékban. Igaz ezzel a szerencse szerepe is megnő, mert jó húzás esetén sok pontot gyűjthet a játékos 1-2 állomás lehelyezésével, rossz esetben viszont gyűlnek a mínuszok.
Mivel kisebb a pálya, így azt találták ki, hogy csak hat nagy útvonal kártya van és több kicsi. Szerintem ez fölösleges volt. Jobb lett volna, ha marad az eredeti játék szerinti egyforma útvonalkártya, különböző hosszú útvonalakkal.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Another classic case of subtraction by addition.  While not a big fan of the original, I feel it works well enough as a light intro game, but this game feels absolutely random.  The base mechanic in both of the games is Draw, Draw, Draw, Draw, Play, kind of boring (and random if you are waiting for what you need) but whatever.  

This new version is worse, because it adds awkward requirements to the randomness.  In this there are routes that require wild cards, but if you don't ever have to chance to get a wild card you cannot do a thing about it, you just draw waiting for the game to end.  

If you aren't constrained enough by the drafting choices, now there is a new rule to add randomness -- tunnels.  Now you never know if you are going to actually get to build, so planning is pretty much thrown out the window.  If you don't have enough cards to cover random extra payments to build the game incorporates the worst mechanic you can incorporate in any game, you lose your turn.  So, rather than risk losing your turn you can take two or three extra turns to countermand the absurd luck.  

I was hoping that this game would solve some of the problems of the previous game, but this again has the same petering endgame where people feel that they have nothing significant to do for the last 4 or 5 turns.  My time is better spent doing just about anything else, than waste my time on this dross.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.98

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ticket To Ride is zo'n typisch spel dat bijna iedereen wel kan bekoren. De eenvoud van de regels, de spanning om je bestemmingen te halen en het dwarsbomen van je medespelers maken van dit bordspel een kanjer. De speeltijd blijft ook lekker strak en daar door is de optie van "nog een spelletje?" erg groot.

Bij Ticket To Ride proberen spelers op een map steden door middel van treinroutes met elkaar te verbinden. Die routes bestaan uit kleuren, die de speler met het verzamelen en afleggen van de juiste kleur kaarten moet behalen. Het spel is zo opgebouwd dat elke stad meerdere keren in het bestemmings deck kan voorkomen. Hierdoor weten spelers nooit van elkaar of ze wel de enige zijn die bepaalde stad of route moeten aandoen. Daardoor moet je vaak weer op zoek naar een andere mogelijkheid om je steden te verbinden en je natuurlijk weer andere spelers begint te dwarsbomen enz... Op het einde worden namelijk punten afgetrokken van routes die niet voltooid zijn. 

Ticket To Ride is diverse variaties verkrijgbaar,  meestal andere mappen met verschillende werelddelen en steden. Er zijn bij elke expansion ook kleine spelvariaties mogenlijk op de basis regels.

RATING: 7
2.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My group likes this one a great deal. I like it too, but it's a 7.5 kinda like. It's fun for sure, and makes for a great game to bring out with non-gamers. The awesome part is that after the game we often lament about how "i was trying to do this" and "oh man, i almost got that" - fun aftertalk. Note that my rating is only true if played with gamers who are not of the "I will screw you every chance I get" variety. It can end up a simple block-fest if played with these types of gamers, so we play it much less confrontationally. Much like the Settlers of Catan, this game suffers from a high luck mechanic (flipping cards), although in this game it is much, much less frustrating than in the former - mainly because in Settlers you can immediately see how others benefit from certain die rolls and how you get skunked, whereas in Ticket to Ride the effect of an opponents card flip may not be readily apparent to you. The mechanic of rolling dice or flipping cards is very attractive to non or new gamers because it gives one the anticipatory feeling of being on the edge of one's seat waiting to see if their color/number will come up. This makes for a fun, exciting time at first, but in time begins to pale and become more of a frustrating and very uninspiring (and even "cheap and easy" seeming) game mechanic and design choice. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Adds some stuff to the base game, and is just as good if not better.

New/Sealed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Truly a great game! Played well over a 100 times on the Europe map alone (probably around 200 plays for the series as a whole) and still a regualar and welcome game to my gaming table.
It's a racing game disguised as a set collecting and route building game. The ending is always nailbiting. Quite a feat for a game played over a 100 times! Will I finish all my destination tickets in time? Damn, I need just one more yellow card! Oh no, these tickets I drew are no good! Can I make a detour? 
It's a lighter, family style game, with a luck element in drawing tickets and the coloured cards. Still, timing your moves and positioning yourself on the board well wins you the game more often than not.
As a houserule, we don't use the stations and we mix in the long routes with the regular ones: the different coloured backs offer more information when drawing tickets and there happers to be a long route on top, but the risk is also greater. Trying to link three long routes and succeeding is the best way to win!

Besides being a great game, as it really is a lot of fun to play, it's also the best gateway game. Period.

Owned expansions: Europe 1912

Ticket to Ride ranking: #1

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't like most of the new changes to the game in Ticket to Ride: Europe.  The shift of focus to smaller routes, the stations, and the tunnels all move away from what I absolutely loved about the main game.  The long, hard to get routes were exciting to chase after and compete for, the fear of being blocked off from a route you need for a major ticket added exquisite tension, and when you did achieve something you knew there wasn't another random element to throw a wrench in the works.  The tunnels are the least offending of the new changes but I feel they were only added to arbitrarily increase the difficulty due to the loss of so many 5-6 train routes.

All that said the main game that I love is still mostly intact and a new map of routes is a welcome addition to make the game new and fresh again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
0909 - plays 1, rating 7
Simple and reasonable fun train game. Most important are the mission cards, if you draw the right ones you will win, or maybe more on the point, if you don't get any god, fitting mission you will have to spend turns trying to find one while the oppositions are building rail and winning the game. Stations makes the game "easier" than the original and missions more possible to complete.

RATING: 10
Oh, I love me some route planning and this is the perfect game for that with long, long (and some shorter) train routes to build across a last century Europe. Set collecting is a mechanism I like, this game is light but the ending can come very tense when you are not sure whether you will be able to finish all your routes.
I am aware that some think this game is too solitary but I obviously do not mind that, and yes, had a phase being very addicted to this. Right now I don't own a copy but hope that will change, maybe I will opt for one of the variants instead to try something slightly different.
Own a copy and still love it, whereas Settlers has lost some of its appeal for me over the years, I am still 100% into this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
A laid-back, straightforward game that is easy to grasp. Doesn't have very many difficult decisions. Good mix of control and randomness with the multiple routes per city, the blind draw of trains, and anticipation of other players' turns.

Loved the addition of stations. I think they are a bit expensive to use, but in a bind, they are useful for freeing up a route that might otherwise not be accessible for you.

Ferries are a pretty useless addition to the game in my opinion. Tunnels on the other hand add a bit more anticipation and excitement as each card is turned over form the top of the draw deck. Always fun to see someone trying to build an 8 train tunnel to Stockholm.

UPDATE 2017-06-30: The main problem with Ticket to Ride as a gateway game, for me, is that it's not in any genre I really like very much. Which means that if I'm introducing someone to modern boardgames using Ticket to Ride, whether or not they like Ticket to Ride doesn't really say much on whether they might like the games I really like…

It remains in my shelf for now, but I wouldn't replace it if I lost it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The Europe edition of Ticket to Ride adds a couple more interesting aspects to the game, but not enough to really capture my imagination.  I initially thought these new elements made the game slightly more fun, until I played the Marklin edition and realized that I was feeling a little relieved at not having to think about tunnels and ferries (although the tunnels do add some brief moments of tension and could have been kept).  The train stations seem to take away from the competitiveness of the game by giving a player an "out" if s/he gets stuck, and should perhaps have more value at the end of the game if unplayed.  All in all, I personally thought that TTR: Marklin had the highest fun factor of the three.  Game design: 3.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 1.5/5  Total: 5/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great for playing with people who wouldn't really enjoy Tigris & Euphrates :)

RATING: 8
I like the added complexity that the tunnels & ferries provide in this version.  The added option of the train stations not only provide a nice out when trying to complete an impossible ticket but also add a new layer of strategy because they can give you an easy way of completing tickets at a cost of only 4 victory points.  Nice addition!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[DoW 2005 edition] {Trains; drafting, connection, set collection; optimal 4-5p} A good family game for all kinds of players. I will introduce this game to genera players to let them enter the world of board games. Days of Wonder is gifted to produce beautiful games. This is no exception: parts are very beautiful and durable. My friends love this game already by its outlook. 

TtR:E has different feels for 2-3p and 4-5p players. In a 4-5p game, the value of each route increase vastly and the game will be more competitive and thus funnier. TtR:E is not a deep game but it still provides multiple ways of scoring, decisions between attacks or defense, etc. Nonetheless, players can usually make the decision easily. It's important to collect train cards. More cards give a player more tactic alternatives. However, there is a problem that players may hoard cards actively and the flow of the game may seriously be disrupted when no one is willing to place trains. This won't happen much for casual gamers, though. Another problem is that the value of each route is not well tuned. Some routes are clearly more important than others and everyone will try to claim that early. Another problem is that the values of tickets are not well-tuned; some tickets are more valuable than others and it's easy for a player to claim many tickets around a particular route and region and win the game easily. Nevertheless, the rule of TtR:E is better than Ticket to Ride: additional kinds of routes and stations so that a player is not easily blocked when all their wanted routes are occupied.

RATING: 7.5
Variation of the orginal, with some added rules.  However, I am not sure that the alterations make the game any better, just different.  The addition of tunnels and ferries certainly make line building more of a challenge, which takes away one of the great enjoyments of the US version.  But the addition of Stations also creates the possibility of getting back what has been denied.  So the sum of all the changes means that it is more or less the same as the original but doesn't flow quite as smoothly.  The same, only different.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game, easy to learn and play. Very strategic as you can only take one action per turn. It definitely builds up the tension as you wait for your turn to come around and hoping no one foils your plans to build the railway to bring you to the win. This version of the game introduces train stations which allows players to utilize the routes claimed by other players to complete their objectives; however, you do not get to count those trains towards your total points. The less train stations you use, the better (as they are worth points in the end). This version also introduces tunnels which may result in a route segment being much longer than anticipated!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favourites... never seen anyone not liking this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ticket to ride is an easy game to play. On your turn, you either pick two cards, or place trains. There are some constraints on those two actions, but that is basically it.

But, the game is perfect for the whole family and casual gamers. No need to worry about the rules. You can just focus on playing.

Not a lot of tough decisions, but it does provide excitement when everybody wants the same routes, trying to find an alternative that could provide you with an advantage.

For me the challenge comes from trying to connect all my routes to obtain the longest train bonus, while completing all my cards, and using all of my trains. And trying to guess where to other players are going to avoid getting blocked.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Only purpose, I played this so often (and will play it in the future), is that it is among the favourite games of some of my regular gaming group, and I enjoy their company so much, I will give in on request.

But I think, the choices are really limited most of the time. To often you can only draw two random cards from top of the deck for several consecutive turns, and this really gets boring, or even frustrating. Game drags and overstays it's welcome most of the times with me, and I'm generally not somebody with short attention span, who feels comfortable with many games much longer then this one.

Regarding this particular map: I think, the connection Stockholm - Petrograd is overpowered. Most times, the person claiming it will win the games.

RATING: 7
Europe adds stations that mitigate blocking. In other TtR games, concerted blocking can cause a +20 to -20 point swing; in Europe a block costs -3 pts, 1-3 cards, a turn, and opportunity cost not being able to complete more tickets. The best TtR.

RATING: 8

The station house seems to prevent aggressive players from attempting "take that" gameplay, which I don't think is positive.  However station houses can be great for higher player games it seems.  The extra elements are abit bitey too, the tunnels element adds a risk factor and the fairys make for a higher stakes wildcard game.  That being said the game is basically the same as the original in most ways, I could play either quite happily!

RATING: 7.6
An incredibly tight variation on Ticket to Ride that at the same time leads to less of the confrontation that the original had, due to the presence of the stations.  An ingenious idea that prevents some of the hard feelings some would get by blocking, while still preserving the need to grab key routes as soon as possible, since unused stations are worth bonus points.

RATING: 9
This game goes over well with just about everyone. Turns fly by at a very nice pace, and there is a pleasant amount of tension - can I make my routes before they're blocked?  - Should I take tickets, even though I will loose tempo doing it, and risk getting bad ones? - Do I take the joker, that I know I can use, or gamble that something good is in the deck? All within quite a short timeframe - excellent!

RATING: 7

RATING: 7

Most Americans will have trouble with the countries and this can make the game drag a bit while people check their routes. It's a good gateway game, but only a gateway game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Not only the best "gateway" game ever created, the TTR series might have the best rules of any game in recent history. The games are simple, play quickly, have great components, and offer a ton of fun choices. The European version is slightly more complicated than the American version, but still increadibly simple. The changes in the European version make scoring with a lot of destination tickets a more viable strategy than in the American version. It is also harder to block your opponent, so this version doesn't feel as cut-throat. Despite being slightly more complicated, I think the changes in this version make it easier for kids and novices to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Good, but a bit of better balancing would have been better.  Specifically, if you can play the east side of the map it is highly preferable because that is where all the longer length tracks (thereby better from a points perspective) reside.  Also, I dislike the long/short Destination ticket scheme of the original game.  I have the 1912 expansion on the way, and hope that the 'Big Cities' game will cure these (in my opinion) drawbacks.  However, I loved the addition of stations in TtRE.

RATING: 8

This can severely handicap a less experienced player.  The train stations are a nice addition, but make play less confrontational.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Curiously popular with the friends that I game with. I find that it's altogether too random in terms of gameplay: you are at the mercy of the cards, and in the closing stages of the game, it ceases to be fun turning over card after card in the desperate search for the one card that will keep you in the game. Add to that the 'clumping' that frequently occurs when routes converge, and you have a recipe for a poorly spent few hours, unless you picked up a good hand.

RATING: 8
I enjoyed Ticket to Ride, but felt like this version would be a better fit for the people that I usually want to play Ticket to Ride with.  It's true, it feels a bit less cut-throat.  I really like the distribution of the destinations better (although I probably could have gotten similar from 1910).  The route distribution will take some getting used to (all those 4-routes, no 5's, and only the 2 6's).  matching color to destination seems less important.  Short-version: it feels pretty different from America, for reasons different from what I expected.  I like it just about the same, but it's fresher, and I think the people around me will like it better.

Oddly the people around me like it less well overall, because of the difficulty of finding European cities (made more difficult with the European names rather than anglicized ones).  I think I actually like it a little better though...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Entretenido y dinamico
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent entry/family game. Rules are very simple and it's easy to get into. There is limited interaction in cock-blocking routes; I like the big playing board also. There is much comparison between Thurn and Taxis and this game and I would say this one is better suited for beginners as it has a stronger visual/physical element in the train pieces (in addition, it's ironic how both games are rather lacking without their expansion!). Although there is strategy involved there is a lot of chance in what cards you pick up to build routes. With four players there is a lot of tension with certain routes/areas getting congested, which always feels fun. What I do not like is the very limited variability in the rules. You are forced into having one of six long routes so it does become rather obvious after a few plays what people are likely to be going after. The Europa 1912 expansion addresses this and I would have to say it's an essential purchase if you like the base game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game that almost anyone can get into.  Works well with the in-laws and non-gamers as an intro game.  Just enough decisions to keep a hardcore gamer interested while still introducing newbies to the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[Rated 2005/12/05 based on 16 plays]

I prefer this one to the original if playing with gamers rather than family / friends.  Not just for the extra rules - although they are fun and add a bit more weight to the decision-making, but mostly because the board is so much tighter.  More opportunities to interfere with each other's plans, and also more variation in strategy - "lots of small tickets" and "short links, longest train" both work better here than on the USA board.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7
