=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Based one on play, I am not enamored of it.  I'm very uncertain about the station mechanic, in that, if you use one or two, but other players don't, they get a point differential at the end of the game that could sink you.  While I think the long route card mandate is a good idea, the board itself works against you if you have to perform a lot of scoring to catch up or stay ahead.  There are very few 6 and 8 car routes, no 5 car routes at all.  This levels the playing field too much, I think.  As with the original TTR, I also belive it will scale well only with 4 or 5 players.  2 and 3 players games leave the board very empty and thus, no strategy is needed at all.  I would argue that the scale of the map is wrong, and needs reworking in order to produce more meaningful connections between cities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
1.96
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
A better sequel after Ticket to Ride America. Beautiful parts. Revised rules help balancing the game quite bit. One flaw is the inconsistence of ticket values. The game suffers also from under-estimating the tactical values of the short trains in the central western of europe. The unbalanced configuration makes it less enjoyable/replayable to serious gamers after realizing the mis-balanced elements. It does provide strategies, but I would always have access to another better game, unless playing it casually.
By the way, Ticket to Ride: Europe is defintely a good recommendation to new gamers and casual gamers. I may own a copy... if the unbalanced factors are fixed. No plan to get it yet anyway.

08/2008:7.5
Game is not unlike TTR. I am not quite convinced that the additional features such as ferries, tunnels and stations make such a huge difference in the game. Of all the new features, I do like the stations best. It goes well with the game because the the map is tighter and point-scoring is closer. My initial impression, after 1 play, is that this is a tighter, more unforgiving game, and that I like it a little more.  Its hard to be objective because I won that game by being the only person who wasn't getting screwed left and right.  Noone was trying to block, but there is was.  I know I like it at least as much as TtR, and I think despite its close relation with that game, it fills a different niche.  For example, I would not pull out Europe to teach a newbie.  I will rate it the same for now, and adjust accordingly after future plays.

RATING: 5.5
Pros: gateway game with network building mechanic, easy to learn

Cons: no direct player interaction, high degree of luck, limited strategic options

A game I struggle to win, though it baffles me as to why. Pretty straightforward strategy--I seemingly always succumb to bad luck. Frustrating for not only myself but for my wife as well because you get boxed into your strategy and don't have an opportunity to switch it around. You're victim to the card draw as well--in almost every game I play, I feel like I'm simply waiting around for the right color I need to complete a route. We only ever brought it to the table if we had someone who really wanted to play and/or needed a lighter-weight game.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ticket To Ride on a Europe map that adds several main rule changes. I'm not a big fan of the additional randomness associated with the tunnel card draws - the original game (& Marklin) already have what I consider the right balance of randomness inherent in the "rummy" mechanism. I also dislike the imbalance in the map - there are very few long routes and one "super long" 8-train route. Completing that single 8-train route is a viable strategy (worth a very long ticket in points) and is often enough to put you over the top for the win. I do see the necessity for the stations, due to the tightness of the map and the ease by which you can be blocked - I appreciate their implementation. Still a decent game, as are all of the TtR variants, but the weakest of the series in my opinion.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Pity that most of the maps have almost always some border mistakes (compared to time showed on the ticket cards) but that is not a real problem. ; ) Good game with a lot of expansions that will keep boredom away.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
All around solid and fun family game, and I consider it to be the 21st century replacement for "Monopoly" -- as a game everyone who owns a couple of board games tends to have.

It's a game of building railroads, and there are several international variations. The only problem with this game is that the cell-phone app and online version, where you play against several AI opponents, is so good and fast, that you can play a game in 5-10 minutes, so you may get impatient with the 45-60 minute board game in real life once you are spoiled by the app version. 

There are many versions, with railroad systems across many countries or continents, but the Europe version is my favorite right now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Best TTR for 5 players because of stations, which reduce the chances you will be blocked out and stuck with incomplete tickets.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Griffon Library
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I originally started playing Ticket to Ride on my iPad as I was unsure how much re playability it would have with my gaming group and I wanted to see if it was something that my wife would like.

Turns out this is one of our favorite games and my wife loves it!

It is incredibly easy to explain (under 5 minutes), so it's always the game I take out when we have newcomers to the group. However, it never gets boring for the more experienced gamers as there is always new strategies to try (mean if you are playing against other cutthroat players, or fast and loose with the newcomers).

The component quality is very high with my only complaint being that the plastic could be just a bit heavier as it seems really easy for the trains to scoot around the board with even the lightest nudge. 

I also prefer Europe to the original game. Drawing tickets in the original can be make or break (whether or not you get a high pointer), but Europe balances that out with 2 low tickets and 1 high ticket per person. They also add train stations so that getting blocked isn't as catastrophic anymore. The map also uses the European names of cities which I found was a nice touch as it gets me into the theme even more.

A fantastic game (and a fantastic app) that I'd highly recommend to people new to games, experienced with games, or who don't even know how truly fun games can be!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Enjoyable game!  I owned Nordic already but got this version to have a game that scales up to 5 players.  Prefer this one to the original USA version because the locomotives and tunnels add much-appreciated complexity to the game.  I would not enjoy this game nearly as much without them!  Stations are a new addition in Europe.  I expected to have a "take them or leave them" opinion, but I ended up using them more than I expected.  I could still live without in a 2-3p setting, but in a 5p game they become more critical.

If you're playing with 2-3 players, I'd still recommend Nordic as the way to go.  If you want a game that can scale up to 5, go with Europe.  This one plays okay with 3, but I think I'll always enjoy Nordic more with only 2.

The only reason I'm giving this one a lower score than Nordic is because of the cards.  The Nordic cards have better artwork and feel a little more durable.  If I have to look at cards for an entire game, I'd rather be looking at the ones from Nordic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Simple abstract game. There's some strategy but luck has an important role. More players make it more chaotic. Fast paced. Fine quality of bits.
It has a few extra rules to improve it (some are fine, like the new initial tickets, while some simply add randomness, like tunnels).
The map has more (and shorter) routes to encourage playing more than hoarding.
Overall, slightly better than the original.

RATING: 7
Rated after 9 played games. A little bit too easy for my taste, usually everyone can build pretty all the routes using the stations and the tunnels are irritating. I prefer the original version, it's tougher, more competitive and more evil.

Update after tenth game, now with a more competitive group. The game felt different and not at all as family game as before. Was this a one time miracle, we will see in the future.

Add about 13 two-player games in couple of days, but the game is not at its best as two-player game. On most of the games, the map is too open and it is rather easy to finish the routes and the stations are almost useless. Ok game, finishes in 30 minutes and sometimes it is very tight.

Update after three 3-player games. The game is better with 3 than 2 players, the map is tighter and there is need for the stations. Playable with two, still.

Over 30 games, updated the rating to 7. The game is good, especially with three players.

Almost 50 plays now, I seem to have not updating the Comment or the later edits have disappeared... The game is good and with different maps it is easy to get a good play for different number of players and get some variety as well.

RATING: 7
I've had two plays for far... And I don't really know where I stand with this game yet.  I'll have to play it again.

Simply put; the game play two fold; draw cards to try to make sets in your hand, and then play those sets to lay down train lines between cities on the map.

Points are scored by simply laying traintracks and by completing routes which are on separate cards that you draw.

Pretty light-weight 'train themed' game.

I do see some improvements with the game, through the shorter ticket routes and the more crowded nature of the board.

1 play: 3 players
2 plays: 4 players
7 plays: 5 players

RATING: N/A
Ticket to Ride: Europe takes you on a new train adventure across Europe. From Edinburgh to Constantinople and from Lisbon to Moscow, you'll visit great cities of turn-of-the-century Europe. More than just a new map, Ticket to Ride: Europe  features brand new gameplay elements including Tunnels, Ferries and Train Stations. The game also includes larger format cards and Train Station game pieces.
\13\\13\
Like the original Ticket to Ride, the game remains elegantly simple, can be learned in 5 minutes, and appeals to both families and experienced gamers. Ticket to Ride: Europe is a complete, new game and does not require the original version.
\13\\13\
Ticket to Ride Synopse:\13\
With elegantly simple gameplay, Ticket to Ride can be learned in 3 minutes, while providing players with intense strategic and tactical decisions every turn. Players collect cards of various types of train cars they then use to claim railway routes in North America. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who fulfill Destination Tickets - goal cards that connect distant cities; and to the player who builds the longest continuous route.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A really simple, quick, rewarding game with just enough tension. The original Ticket to Ride was one of the early "hobby games" that I played; it was good, but I like this one better because the Stations and the long routes make this game a bit less luck-dependent. It's a small thing, but I also like how each of the cities is labeled with its local name. Great as a gateway game, but also sstill rewarding for me to play years on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
With elegantly simple gameplay, Ticket to Ride can be learned in under 15 minutes, while providing players with intense strategic and tactical decisions every turn. Players collect cards of various types of train cars they then use to claim railway routes. The longer the routes, the more points they earn. Additional points come to those who fulfill Destination Tickets – goal cards that connect distant cities; and to the player who builds the longest continuous route.

RATING: 7.355
Ticket To Ride is much-neglected by experienced gamers as they tend to move on to games with more interesting and novel mechanics, but I don't think that the simple gameplay of Ticket to Ride should be underappreciated.  It's very simple to teach yet provides a very solid and reliable gaming experience. The Europe map is probably the friendliest, so if you want something with more tension and conflict, then perhaps invest in a map pack.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
After a day spent with TTR:E I conclude: the replayability is great and the rules are extremely easy. It can be played with casual gamers as well as pro-gamers and there is no great difference in the ability of scoring points. The tunnels make the game even more exciting and add to the tension.We seldomly used the Stations, but almost anyone tries to get the bonus points for the longest railroad. What's a litte sad is, that there is very few long tickets as well as only two long lines one can build, both of which are either a tunnel or a ferry. This does not diminish the fun, thgugh and it is only notable, if one knows Marklin Edition or the original one.And it really needs only about an hour to play, which is really great.Finally, the downtime is extremely low, even with 4 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Review Date: May 2017

Positives: Simple to learn. THE modern gateway game. You can play with gamers or grannies. Satisfying and has enough depth to entertain most

Negatives: Once you are into the hobby, you will probably find this too light and want to play almost anything else given a chance  


Conclusion: Probably the most vanilla modern board game there is. It will not upset, it will not excite, but it will allow you to play a board game with friends/family who might otherwise never play a board game
 

Score 7....Zzzzzz

RATING: 8
A modern classic. Develops the original Ticket to Ride idea into something more balanced, with more variety and in a location more familiar to people I play with. Good as a family game or as lighter fare for gamers to wind-down with.
Stations reduce the chance of getting completely blocked, making this suitable for friendly games with relatives. However, it is still possible to play some cut-throat moves, so it's not all fluffy and nice.
The introduction of ferries and tunnels gives added value to locomotive cards. 
Splitting the tickets into short and long routes works well, although some of the tickets are noticeably weaker than others (Edinburgh-Athens springs to mind).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My favorite of the series of three TTR games. I love the unpredictability factor presented by the introduction of the Tunnels. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Having played TTR: US, India, Switzerland, and Africa, it seemed that the next best step was Europe. I traded Flash Point: Fire Rescue for it, and despite the cost difference from what I provided (with expansions) for Europe, I'm still very happy with the trade.

Europe is generally rated/reviewed higher than US, and for good reason. Europe adds just a couple of new twists that aren't overly complex, but still make you think through how you want to proceed. If you have just one TTR game, make it Europe. 

(I do not yet own the 1912 expansion, but hope to sometime in the future.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like it, have played it many times but on balance prefer TTR US, as there is more flexibility in building long routes, and I find the route cards better balanced.

RATING: 8
Simple mechanics, and great length. Similar to the table card game "rummy" in many ways and especially in the scoring system.

House Rule: Allow two actions per turn, one draw action (ticket OR train cards) AND one placement action (station OR route). Additionally, you may not play face-up draws immediately.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
I have to say, it was one of the most underwhelming games I've ever played. One play is enough to tell me that I never need to play TtR again. 

Over half the game is spent drawing cards. Further, luck of the draw is an incredibly big factor, masked by several turn options which create the illusion of mitigating luck, while instead simply exacerbating the good fortune of others... You spend turns drawing more cards, trying for more tickets or placing stations or laying track along tunnels and failing, while players who have tickets in close proximity, or drawing the colors they need, or jumping into a railway without the need for a station or who never draw extra cards to sink into tunnel development pull away.

Incredible production value, but one of the least interesting, least strategically compelling games I've ever played. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
A much tighter game than its predecessor.  I enjoy the new mechanics, and there aren't as many throw away routes that plague the USA map (especially in the mid-central area).  I found TTR Europe riskier, more nerve racking, and just overall a more satisfying experience.  Definitely my preferred choice to play.

Update: I knocked 0.5 point off the score because after playing it for a while, I felt that the Europe map also suffered from a lack of synergy in the destination cards.  The game more often than not is also reduced to making the longest route (like in USA); there is almost no point to drawing more tickets since claiming the only 6 and/or 8 length tracks on the board will usually net you a higher score.

RATING: 9.1
Lots of fun and fairly simple. No lack of action - tuns usually move very fast. Doesn't provoke as much table talk as many other games though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ferries requiring locomotives is an interesting touch, though since they're around the perimeter, a player may never have to face that challenge in a game.  The stations are a nice compensation for being otherwise cut off from connecting a ticket's destinations, especially with the tradeoff of their being worth 4 points each if you can spare them.  The tunnels, though, are what bring greater suspense to the game.  Making sure you have enough extra cars of that color (or locomotives) you have in your hand before connecting a tunnel, so you don't effectively miss a turn, while trying to minimize time wasted in collecting cards you don't need is a nice element of gambling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
A slightly steeper learning curve than the original, but deeper and better in my opinion. I've you are American it will probably take you a little bit to get your bearings and remember where all of this turn of the century European cities are. Regardless, it is a great game for just about everyone. Break this out and have a great time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Classic gateway game. Play it with your non-gamer friends and have a blast. Definite step up from Monopoly or suchlike.

RATING: 8
I have played this one a few times now. The game requires a reasonable sense of geography, and hence leaves me at a distinct disadvantage. You are required to build train routes between European cities as outlined on rail tickets distributed at the start of the game. Naturally, you need the correct material to do it, and obstacles such as tunnels and other players form quite a hinderance... Much more fun to play than the quirky descriptions its given might lead you to believe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Build a train empire across Europe to score points and block your opponents. Players collect sets of cards of different colours from a central supply and use them to claim routes on the board. Tickets can give you extra points for connecting certain cities, but leaving them incomplete will lose you points at the end.

Theme: Early 20th century trains
Mechanic: Set collection / route building
Ideal players: 2-5
Length: Medium
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
One of the best games ever! You can teach the rules in 5 minutes and it's still enjoyable for hundreds of sessions. We have introduced it to unexperienced gamers aged 7 through 70. Everyone of them have enjoyed the game and many have bought their own copy. I think we will play it again tonight!
